<h3><span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
column10: >With eight years of experience as a screenwriter and two as a  producer, director and cameraman
column11: I've decided to write and direct my first short film: Language Barrier.

column1: Oh, my name? Right. My name is Manuel Ortega-Caro and filming has been my passion since I was a little kid.  Ever since I was 20,
column5: >I've been blessed working with a production company filming small documentaries and TV Spots.  I'm the
column13: >The Teen Pet Vet with Ninoshka,
column15: >a TV Spot that airs in PBS Puerto Rico.

column3: />
/>

column1: I also do small documentaries for Puerto Rico's DOE where I function as the Writer/Cameraman/Director/Producer/Interviewer.

column3: />
/>

column4: >But enough about me! Let's talk about this project: Language Barrier. It's a multi-language short film that tells three stories of immigrants from different countries and how their interactions, despite the language barrier, could change their lives forever.
>What's different about this short film that makes it so special?

>I came up with this idea when I moved to New York and saw a variety ethnics, cultures, races and then it hit me: We got so much more things in common than we think. We`re always focused on how different we are from each other that we ignore how similar we really are.  This movie encourages people to speak an universal, yet forgotten, language and that's the language of love.

column1: <h3>What We Need &amp

Let's talk business now. I need $20,000 to make this wonderful dream come true. For the first time I'm working with a very talented cast and an amazing crew and I want to respect and value their talent.  So, yes
column2: I need to pay them, feed them and cover their transportation expenses. I also need to cover the location fees, permit fees (for a subway station scene), props rental fees for the hospital scene, post-production work (editing), and the entry fees for the Short Film Festivals all around the world.

column1: WE HAVE AMAZING PERKS!
$1 - Spread your happiness- Thank you in our facebook page.
$10 - Share a smile – Your smile in our Facebook page.
$50 - Offer a hug – speak love t-shirt.
$75 - Give a kiss – digital copy of the film, speak love t-shirt and poster
$100 - Share your blessings – digital copy of the film plus EXTRAS, speak love t-shirt and poster
$500– Wipe a tear - Special thanks on film, a personalized thank you message from director and cast, digital copy of the film plus EXTRAS, speak love t-shirt and poster.

$1000 – Speak love - You'll get an executive producer credit on the film or get your company promotion on film,  a personalized thank you message from director and cast, digital copy of the film plus EXTRAS, speak love t-shirt and poster.
The Impact

After millions of years of evolution, human beings have not learned how to coexist peacefully. Differences in race, sexual orientation, religion are still reasons to hate one another.  It just breaks my heart to see so many manifestations of hate lately. You can see it written on the walls, shout out in public, at schools at work... Minorities being attacked are becoming more common each day that passes. And the scary part is that people are starting to see this as normal.  In times like this, more than ever before, we need to share this film to the world.  A film that shows us, despite our differences, how similar we are from each other.  We were designed to be one race, humans and created to speak one language: LOVE.  We can change the course of a life with a kiss, a hug, a cry, a smile, a laughter... and this emotions mean the same thing all around the globe because it's the human's way to speak LOVE.

Films have become a great mechanism to influence in peoples opinions and their way of looking at life. Let Language Barrier be your voice and let us be the voice of those who feel speechless in a world that rejects them for no reason.
Meet the Cast:
ALMERRY MARTINS
SWAY
JYOTI SINGH
INES STORANI
SOOK HYUNG YANG
JARED STANFIELD
JAY AMARI
JONATHAN WEST
Other Ways You Can Help

Please! If you can not support this film economically, at least get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. I will strongly appreciate it. Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools and social networks.
","With eight years of experience as a screenwriter and two as a  producer, director and cameraman
column2: I've decided to write and direct my first short film: Language Barrier.

column1: Oh, my name? Right. My name is Manuel Ortega-Caro and filming has been my passion since I was a little kid.  Ever since I was 20, I've been blessed working with a production company filming small documentaries and TV Spots.  I'm the Writer/Director/Cameraman on The Teen Pet Vet with Ninoshka, a TV Spot that airs in PBS Puerto Rico.
I also do small documentaries for Puerto Rico's DOE where I function as the Writer/Cameraman/Director/Producer/Interviewer.

But enough about me! Let's talk about this project: Language Barrier. It's a multi-language short film that tells three stories of immigrants from different countries and how their interactions, despite the language barrier, could change their lives forever.
What's different about this short film that makes it so special?

I came up with this idea when I moved to New York and saw a variety ethnics, cultures, races and then it hit me: We got so much more things in common than we think. We`re always focused on how different we are from each other that we ignore how similar we really are.  This movie encourages people to speak an universal, yet forgotten, language and that's the language of love.
What We Need & What You Get

Let's talk business now. I need $20,000 to make this wonderful dream come true. For the first time I'm working with a very talented cast and an amazing crew and I want to respect and value their talent.  So, yes
column2: I need to pay them, feed them and cover their transportation expenses. I also need to cover the location fees, permit fees (for a subway station scene), props rental fees for the hospital scene, post-production work (editing), and the entry fees for the Short Film Festivals all around the world.

0,"

WHAT IT'S ALL ABOUT

If you haven't owned one, you know someone who has. If you don't know someone who has, you've surely seen some smiling Volkswagen bus - and its smiling Volkswagen driver - rumbling down the street at a charmingly slow pace. And I bet it made you smile. I bet it made your 87-year-old grandmother smile. I bet it made your four-year-old niece positively giddy.

I know, I know. Volkswagen buses are just vehicles. And I'll be the first to admit that I'm not really a car person. But this is that rare car that has a true spirit: the bus embodies its vehicular identity by inspiring people to get on the road, take some risks and embrace whatever comes next. And it's been doing this for over fifty years. What other car can say they've won a fifty-year-and-counting popularity contest?
column2:
>


THE IDEA

The goal of The Volkswagen Story Project is to capture the spirit of VW buses through the words and photos of the people who keep them alive. The project will start with a loop through much of the West Coast - seven weeks of meeting bus folks, collecting their stories and taking their photos. These stories and photos will eventually become a bound book that tells the story of the bus and its people
column3:
in the meantime, updates will be posted on vwstoryproject.com.


THE STORY

Every Volkswagen owner, past and present, has a story to tell. My story started with a yellow sticky note.

It was spring, and the green bus parked a few blocks away from my house had been teasing me for years. Her cute green face stared happily ahead, every day, never moving from her spot. So I wrote something like, ""To whomever owns this bus: I've noticed it sitting here for the last four years and just wonder what its story is."" I left my email address and drew a little bus on the note for good measure, figuring I'd never hear back. But a few days later, I got my reply. ""You asked for my story..."" it read. ""Here's a start. I will be 39 in November of this year. I am the youngest, yet the largest and strongest of all that have come before me. I've been loved, hated, cussed at and praised everywhere I've ever traveled to or lived..."" And it went on, for two weird and beautiful paragraphs.

It was at once the oddest and most amazing email I had ever received. After a week, I finally managed a response. ""I will be 23 in July of this year,"" I wrote. ""Since I can remember I have felt a distinct identification with VW buses, and strong attraction to them, their history, their character, and the stories they create."" It was the beginning of a two-week courtship with a VW bus. Which strangely enough, felt exactly right. 

Through it, I also learned more about the owner of that bus, a man who cared for others for a living - ""kinda like owning a Volkswagen,"" he explained in one email. He shared that, after years of caring for the bus, he had decided to rebuild the engine with his son and send it off with him as a high school graduation gift - a father-son bonding project. But when his son abruptly lost interest partway through, he didn't have the heart to finish the job. So when we finally met in person, Tim told me that he had been awake all night deliberating, and felt unable to put a price tag on a bus that held such deep significance to him. Instead, he wanted to give it to me, its next rightful owner. I named her Bella.

Since that day Bella has served as a living room and creative space before her engine was reassembled, an ambassador to meeting new people as I figured out how to get her back on the road, and a band-mobile/musical inspiration to my bluegrass-folk band. (She's even got a song on our new album!)

Bella has become a feature of Walla Walla street traffic, and recently enjoyed a moment of fame as the feature of a newspaper article. Soon, she and I will soon be embarking on our first road adventure together, along with my intrepid college roommate Suzanne. Tapping into the power of email, Facebook, Instagram, phones, and good old-fashioned sticky notes, we will trace a seven-week loop through the American West, camping and exploring and meeting as many Volks folks as we can.


WHERE YOU COME IN

This project begins with a bus, but it is about people. I want to capture the character of this car by turning the camera on its people. You can follow our journey on our website at vwstoryproject.com. Also look for us on Instagram and Facebook. All three members of this project will need plenty of fuel to get through the summer - all donations will go towards gas and food. 

Please help make this dream a reality!

This is the first of many episodic short films. It is a story out of the mind of writer/director Marc Schryer, which portrays a young boy with a confusing relationship with his mother, he does bad things to girls and animals. He grows up with anger and hatred towards a cult that kidnapped, tortured, drugged, and raped his mother. He is the product of that rape. He is out to kill those who murdered his beloved mother. His accomplice is what he thinks of as an alter ego but in reality is a demon that pushes his buttons to the edge.

Glenn Woods' Bold Republic is a daily syndicated radio program, with listeners around the nation (and the world).  Original, thought-provoking, and funny, Glenn takes national issues and finds the humor while explaining the impact . . . on you!
• We broadcast to terrestrial stations via the internet, but need to make the final ""Push""!
• One little push, up onto THE BIRD, Satellite that is!
<li>Glenn delivers news and commentary with humor
column2: to inform, to inspire, and to promote involvement in local and national issues.  Bold Republic is a ""Smaller-Government - Bigger Freedom"" - radio program that advocates for : Individualism and Liberty.

<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

""Bumpkins"" is a female-driven, rural comedy webseries about Fern and Amber Lynn, best friends learning how to be adults at two different stages in womanhood. They are two medium-sized fish in a small town pond and the series is as if the shows ""Portlandia"" and ""Broad City"" had a country baby. We want to embrace the rural lifestyle and echo comedy and moments that come from the truths of living in a country town.

The story involves Fern and Amber Lynn's daily lives, where they work, where they play, the people they surround themselves with and the rustic atmosphere in which they live. Your contribution will go towards locations, food, and props like canoes, caskets, dog kennels, musical instruments, riding lawn mowers and above-ground pools. We're not gonna  be fancy, we're gonna to be down-home funny.

""Bumpkins"" takes place in a small, country town and will be filmed in Easton, Maryland. We love this setting because it is beautiful, charming and the town encompasses everything the story needs. In this case, production has to travel to the location which means we have to transport things like crew and equipment. Your contributions will allow us to bring in our production requirements.
Our New Approach:

A few weeks ago we launched a Kickstarter that got us attention and some wonderful donations. It peaked people's curiosity about our project and earned us a fantastic audience. The Kickstarter was not fulfilled, therefore, we didn't get the money via that avenue. We have launched this IndieGoGo to help ensure that we can secure funding in both an internet/crowdfunding way as well as by raising awareness and getting attention on the ground, locally in Maryland.
During the month of July, Alexis Morrell will be on the East Coast, in Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware talking to people and gaining to get local support.
Embracing Local Resources:
<figure style=""margin: 0px

We look forward to including local talent, businesses and locations to give the story a truly authentic feel. We want to have local products in our scenes, local talent performing with us, local businesses as locations and the beauty of the Eastern Shore in our shots.
We want this series to be like a hug for the community. We want the series to feel as authentically rural and rustic as possible and the comedy to come from a place we can appreciate as home-grown.
If you are interested in participating, please contact us at bumpkinswebseries@gmail.com for more information and details.
CAST:
<figure style=""margin: 0px
FERN: Alexis Morrell
A little about Fern... 30, works at a dog and cat kennel, single and lives with her parents. She wants it all but really doesn't have her junk together. She loves Leo DiCaprio at any age.
AMBER LYNN: Megan McDermott
A smidge about Amber Lynn... 21, and works at the local grocery store. She's a ""new adult,"" learning as she goes along, seeking information but, most often, led by emotion.
Who We Are:

We are a diverse group of filmmakers who are based in Los Angeles. Our backgrounds range from South Central, LA to Beijing, China to the Eastern Shore of Maryland creating an eclectic creative perspective on storytelling.
Writer/Director: Alexis Morrell
<figure style=""margin: 0px

Alexis was raised on the Eastern Shore of Maryland where she committed herself to shenanigans and babysitting. She played lacrosse through college and then moved to Los Angeles to work in the Film/TV industry and to earn her MFA in TV/Film Production from USC's School of Cinematic Arts. She has worked a variety of roles on set (IMDB) and is now writing and directing what she knows. You can follow Alexis on Twitter @alexis_morrell and on Instagram @TheLazyShiksa.
Producer: Katrelle Kindred
<figure style=""margin: 0px

A native of South Los Angeles, Katrelle Kindred completed her graduate studies at the University of Southern California, School of Cinematic Arts, earning a MFA degree in Film and Television Production. A former Subway Fresh Artist winner and recipient of the Johnny Carson Fellowship for academic excellence and Achievement in Cinematic Arts, Katrelle was also selected to direct a short film that will be included in an anthology film, entitled “The Labyrinth,” produced for Rabbit Bandini Productions and mentored by award winning actor, director, and producer, James Franco. Katrelle has directed and produced short films and web content for Sony, Content Co., Hyundai, and various non profit organizations. In the future, Katrelle would like to continue creating honest stories that focus on global social issues and people often unheard.
Writer: Megan McDermott
<figure style=""margin: 0px

Meg McDermott was born and raised in Easton, Maryland, where she spent a lot of time driving around town in a ’97 Honda Civic with one side mirror and eating crabs. She is a a fourth year student concentrating in writing for television in the Dramatic Writing Program at Tisch School of the Arts, has studied improv at the UCB in New York City under Chelsea Clarke and Nicole Drespel and was also a member of NYU’s sketch comedy team, HammerkatzNYU. She currently lives in New York. Keep up with her on Twitter/Instagram@mkatmcd.
Cinematographer: Rachel Han Xu
<figure style=""margin: 0px

Based in Los Angeles, Rachel has been working on advertising and narrative projects locally and globally. Her international upbringing has given her an integrated understanding of both eastern and western world, and has a strong influence on her work.

Originally from Beijing, China, Rachel holds a BA degree in directing from Peking (Beijing) University and an MFA in film/TV production with cinematography emphasis from the University of Southern California.
Production Designer: Cecile Davis
<figure style=""margin: 0px

Cecile “Cece” Davis grew up in Cambridge Maryland, went to college in London England, where she studied theatre, film and art direction. During the six years she lived abroad, she worked with a wide range of artists: from Kevin Spacey at The Old Vic to independent filmmakers like herself. Feeling homesick for the slower pace and quality of life on the eastern shore, she moved home to Easton in 2010, where she was quickly snapped up by Mid-Shore Community Television (a division of the Avalon Foundation) and to this day, despite owning and running her own successful production company, she continues to work for the TV station and film the many events put on by the Avalon Foundation. www.ceciledavisfilms.com
Music by Ahmed Alabaca
<figure style=""margin: 0px

Ahmed Alabaca was raised in a troubled neighborhood in San Bernardino California, Alabaca began composing and playing the piano at age 6, finding an escape from reality in the music that flowed out of him, giving him life. Alabaca moved to New York in the summer of 2006 and readily adjusted to the life of a struggling artist in the city of dreams, buying a keyboard before he bought a bed. For a time all he did was compose and work.While in NYC, Alabaca earned his B.A. in Music from Hunter College, took classes at Julliard, and earned his New York State teaching certificate. Alabaca began to deeply explore scoring while collaborating on original theater projects, using his music as part of the performance “text”, exploring how to make music a vital and necessary part of the artistic whole as opposed to an unnecessary element superimposed onto the production.
Now, after moving back to California, Alabaca is composing and performing for various projects throughout the Los Angeles Area.
Ahmed can be found on Instagram @ahmedalabaca
Agriculture Culture Advisor: Jenna Hicks
<figure style=""margin: 0px
Homegrown in Southern Illinois.
DIRECTOR'S STATEMENT:
Why I am making this:

I think it’s a mixture of living in a small town surrounded by fields, taping over childhood home movies with episodes of “The Nanny” and “SNL” on the family VCR to watch on repeat when my homework was done and a Shania Twain obsession that have led to this moment.

Most writers say to write what you know and I know Fern and Amber Lynn. They are pieces of myself growing up, people I know from home, from college and from other rural areas who are trying to make the most of what they’ve got. The idea for the show came to me when I was just writing a scene for fun about this time I made a huge mistake back home and my dad called the cops on me… The thing is, he didn’t know he called the cops on me. Actually, if he reads this, it might reveal to him that he called the cops on me. I sent the scene to my friend and producing partner, Katrelle Kindred, and she said “Let’s make this.” There’s nothing more rewarding than a mistake paying off creatively. Plus, they can’t fine ya if they can’t find ya. #CountryLogic
I’m presently keeping that story vague as to lure you into watching this series.

I am so proud of the team we have brought together. We have people from all over the world, various backgrounds, ethnicities and stories coming together to make something different, entertaining and above all else, funny. We will be sacrificing time, sweat, tears and dignity to bring you a quality production. I am looking forward to the format as well, something that can be watched in webisode segments but then also enjoyed as a whole, almost as if you were watching a show from television in the 1990s. Do you remember that? I’ll break out the VCR. I still have one.

One last note I want to boast about is our idea of incorporating local crew, talent and businesses. We want “Bumpkins” to have an authentic feel, much like how “Portlandia” or “Broad City” are loyal to their stomping grounds and the people who inhabit them. These characters are your neighbors or your cousins. Everyone gets it, but you don’t really want them to show up at every wedding.
Thank you for being a part of Bumpkins and I can’t wait to show you what we’ve been stirring up! Yee haw!
-Alexis Morrell

PS - Sorry, not sorry Dad. #statuteoflimitations

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

The donations will go towards:

  • Film equipment rentals.

column1: • Transporting talented crew to the location.
• Food for cast and crew.
• Location fees.
• Props and set pieces like canoes, riding lawn mowers, aboveground pools and a casket. That's right... This comedy has everything!

If we don't complete the campaign, we have a flexible funding set up so that any donations received will go towards the project and we will work towards producing the show to the best of our abilities.

The Impact

Our webseries will tell the stories of people from rural America. We are taking stories from growing up on the shore, deep south and mid-west and creating a comedy series to reflect the things that you just don't get in the city.

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Our greatest challenge is to create a high quality series with tons of production value with a small budget. Comedic, innovative, and truthful storytelling are our main goals for this project. However, we want to stay as true to our artistic vision as our budget will allow. Pooling all of our resources together with your financial assistance will allow us to succeed up and beyond!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our webseries and campaign! 
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

column1: • Tweet, text, Facebook, Like, Tumblr and if you can invent a new way of using social media to promote our series, we'd be so grateful!
• Spread the word locally, or contact Alexis when she's in Easton this July.
• Promote your product or local business with us. We'd love to have you involved!
<div>
","Short Summary

""Bumpkins"" is a female-driven, rural comedy webseries about Fern and Amber Lynn, best friends learning how to be adults at two different stages in womanhood. They are two medium-sized fish in a small town pond and the series is as if the shows ""Portlandia"" and ""Broad City"" had a country baby. We want to embrace the rural lifestyle and echo comedy and moments that come from the truths of living in a country town.

The story involves Fern and Amber Lynn's daily lives, where they work, where they play, the people they surround themselves with and the rustic atmosphere in which they live. Your contribution will go towards locations, food, and props like canoes, caskets, dog kennels, musical instruments, riding lawn mowers and above-ground pools. We're not gonna  be fancy, we're gonna to be down-home funny.

Bumpkins"" takes place in a small, country town and will be filmed in Easton, Maryland. We love this setting because it is beautiful, charming and the town encompasses everything the story needs. In this case, production has to travel to the location which means we have to transport things like crew and equipment. Your contributions will allow us to bring in our production requirements.
Our New Approach:

A few weeks ago we launched a Kickstarter that got us attention and some wonderful donations. It peaked people's curiosity about our project and earned us a fantastic audience. The Kickstarter was not fulfilled, therefore, we didn't get the money via that avenue. We have launched this IndieGoGo to help ensure that we can secure funding in both an internet/crowdfunding way as well as by raising awareness and getting attention on the ground, locally in Maryland.
During the month of July, Alexis Morrell will be on the East Coast, in Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware talking to people and gaining to get local support.
Embracing Local Resources:

We look forward to including local talent, businesses and locations to give the story a truly authentic feel. We want to have local products in our scenes, local talent performing with us, local businesses as locations and the beauty of the Eastern Shore in our shots.
We want this series to be like a hug for the community. We want the series to feel as authentically rural and rustic as possible and the comedy to come from a place we can appreciate as home-grown.
If you are interested in participating, please contact us at bumpkinswebseries@gmail.com for more information and details.
CAST:
FERN: Alexis Morrell
A little about Fern... 30, works at a dog and cat kennel, single and lives with her parents. She wants it all but really doesn't have her junk together. She loves Leo DiCaprio at any age.
AMBER LYNN: Megan McDermott
A smidge about Amber Lynn... 21, and works at the local grocery store. She's a ""new adult,"" learning as she goes along, seeking information but, most often, led by emotion.
Who We Are:

We are a diverse group of filmmakers who are based in Los Angeles. Our backgrounds range from South Central, LA to Beijing, China to the Eastern Shore of Maryland creating an eclectic creative perspective on storytelling.
Writer/Director: Alexis Morrell

Alexis was raised on the Eastern Shore of Maryland where she committed herself to shenanigans and babysitting. She played lacrosse through college and then moved to Los Angeles to work in the Film/TV industry and to earn her MFA in TV/Film Production from USC's School of Cinematic Arts. She has worked a variety of roles on set (IMDB) and is now writing and directing what she knows. You can follow Alexis on Twitter @alexis_morrell and on Instagram @TheLazyShiksa.
Producer: Katrelle Kindred

A native of South Los Angeles, Katrelle Kindred completed her graduate studies at the University of Southern California, School of Cinematic Arts, earning a MFA degree in Film and Television Production. A former Subway Fresh Artist winner and recipient of the Johnny Carson Fellowship for academic excellence and Achievement in Cinematic Arts, Katrelle was also selected to direct a short film that will be included in an anthology film, entitled “The Labyrinth,” produced for Rabbit Bandini Productions and mentored by award winning actor, director, and producer, James Franco. Katrelle has directed and produced short films and web content for Sony, Content Co., Hyundai, and various non profit organizations. In the future, Katrelle would like to continue creating honest stories that focus on global social issues and people often unheard.
Writer: Megan McDermott

Meg McDermott was born and raised in Easton, Maryland, where she spent a lot of time driving around town in a ’97 Honda Civic with one side mirror and eating crabs. She is a a fourth year student concentrating in writing for television in the Dramatic Writing Program at Tisch School of the Arts, has studied improv at the UCB in New York City under Chelsea Clarke and Nicole Drespel and was also a member of NYU’s sketch comedy team, HammerkatzNYU. She currently lives in New York. Keep up with her on Twitter/Instagram@mkatmcd.

Originally from Beijing, China, Rachel holds a BA degree in directing from Peking (Beijing) University and an MFA in film/TV production with cinematography emphasis from the University of Southern California.

Cecile “Cece” Davis grew up in Cambridge Maryland, went to college in London England, where she studied theatre, film and art direction. During the six years she lived abroad, she worked with a wide range of artists: from Kevin Spacey at The Old Vic to independent filmmakers like herself. Feeling homesick for the slower pace and quality of life on the eastern shore, she moved home to Easton in 2010, where she was quickly snapped up by Mid-Shore Community Television (a division of the Avalon Foundation) and to this day, despite owning and running her own successful production company, she continues to work for the TV station and film the many events put on by the Avalon Foundation. www.ceciledavisfilms.com
Music by Ahmed Alabaca

Ahmed Alabaca was raised in a troubled neighborhood in San Bernardino California, Alabaca began composing and playing the piano at age 6, finding an escape from reality in the music that flowed out of him, giving him life. Alabaca moved to New York in the summer of 2006 and readily adjusted to the life of a struggling artist in the city of dreams, buying a keyboard before he bought a bed. For a time all he did was compose and work.While in NYC, Alabaca earned his B.A. in Music from Hunter College, took classes at Julliard, and earned his New York State teaching certificate. Alabaca began to deeply explore scoring while collaborating on original theater projects, using his music as part of the performance “text”, exploring how to make music a vital and necessary part of the artistic whole as opposed to an unnecessary element superimposed onto the production.
Now, after moving back to California, Alabaca is composing and performing for various projects throughout the Los Angeles Area.
Ahmed can be found on Instagram @ahmedalabaca

Hi Friends!
Meagan here! You might know me from the internet (@mhanes), various WordCamps in Canada (Montreal, Ottawa, Toronto), or as being your daughter (hi Mom!).

I'm happy to say I'll be attending WordCamp Toronto 2015! In the spirit of our open source community, I would greatly appreciate your support and help to get me there and make Toronto one of the best WordCamps this year.

What's a WordCamp? WordCamps are community-organized, accessible, low price educational conventions where bloggers, web designers and developers, and all other people meet to speak and learn about building websites and making them a success. 2014 saw over 80 WordCamps in every continent around the world (except Antarctica!) and probably one within 100km of you. Answers to all of your web questions, networking with other WordPress users, and a fantastic fun weekend, all at under $40 a ticket - lunch included! Talk about accessible education!
Your support will let me travel with stress-free, stay at a convenient hotel near the venue, and focus on inspiring and educating hundreds of eager designers, developers, and WordPress users.

I've prepared some awesome and FUN perks to express my gratitude (I might even SING about you!) and I sincerely hope you'll help me reach this goal!

How This Works
All funds raised go into my WordCamp Fund, and will be used for hotels, transportation, and food in Toronto. Any excess money raised will remain in the Fund for the next WordCamp!

To contribute, simply enter a dollar amount, or select one of the Perks to the right. Maybe you'd love one of my pencil sketches! Maybe you have a website and would like my website review! Maybe you want to pick my brain and find a diamond! The choice is up to you :)
How Your Contribution Helps

Participating in WordCamps is one way I give back to the technology community and inspire others (especially women) about technology, design, and creativity. Every year my skills improve, and I'm glad to share them for the greater good.

That said, I fund WordCamp participation from my own pocket. This limits how many I can attend. If this crowd funding goes well, I can consider expanding my tour to other WordCamps - New York, Boston, etc!

Help Share the Love!

If you can't contribute financially, no worries! Would you contribute socially?
Please consider sharing this page with your friends, especially if you include a small message of support!
Most of all though, THANK YOU for reading this far and for helping me make this dream a reality!

My name is Jorge Saldana, the director of the new short film Voracity.
Hi Everyone, thanks for taking a look at my Indiegogo page, it means a
lot to me and the whole crew! My crew is currently working hard in the
Pre-Production stage and we are excited to start Production in less than
a month!

Voracity is the story of Caleb Whitton, a homeless man who struggles to reclaim the life he lost.

This story is so important to not just me but my writer, producers and the rest of my crew and colleagues. We want to bring this powerful story to life at the big screen.
<h3>What We Need &amp
column2: What You GetYour generous donations will be the key in making this film go from an

column1: idea, to a reality. Our budget is $1,200, it might seem like a lot, but
all of it will be used to progress the film. All donations will be used
to pay our excellent actors, to feed and provide transportation to the
cast and crew, to acquire production insurance, the rental of film
equipment, to aid production design (which includes props, set design,
wardrobe, and makeup), and to cover film festival entry fees.
Through your generous donations you will receive awesome perks! Perks like:
<ul>
• A Special Thanks in the credits of the film.
• A DVD copy of the film.
• A full sized poster with signed by cast and crew.
• A custom made T-shirt, tank top shirt, hoodie sweatshirt.
• A special personal thank you letter sent directly to you by the Director.
• And finally you will receive the title of ""Executive Producer"" and ""Associative Producer"" in the film's credits and on IMDB (that's a HUGE deal!)
If we don't reach our goal of $1,200 it will set back the film and the process will take a bit longer to make.
Without your help this isn't possible. We want to make the best film we
can and we can't do that without your help!
<div> <h3>Risks &amp
column2: ChallengesThe challenge of making this film just isn't securing our budget, but

column1: completing it all in an 11 week time frame. We have these 11 weeks to
write, produce, fund, film, work on Post-Production, and complete it in
time to premier at the end of March. In reality this isn't an ideal time
frame to complete a film, but with your help and the hard work of our

crew that shouldn't be an issue!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, it's no problem! Spread the word, tell your friends, family and just help us get out there!

is nothing more empowering than speaking up for yourself. SpeakYourStory was
founded on the belief that when you tell your story, not only do you discover
your own strength, but you encourage others to find their voice and stories as

well. We are passionately committed to telling the unfiltered, unedited stories of real women. We've already created an online platform to share these stories, and our success in such a short period of time has led us to dream even bigger.

Our project has been completely self-funded from the beginning,  and this campaign is the next step to bring these stories to life. We are raising money for the first book in a SpeakYourStory Anthology and a 6-episode Podcast series. Story-telling plays an integral role in fighting and overcoming the forces that have marginalized and
dehumanized women throughout history. With your help we will bring the
authentic, beautiful, transformative stories of women into lives all over the
world.

column4: >What We’ve Created So Far
column8: >www.SpeakYourStory.org began as a defiant response to the lack of authentic, real

column1: women’s stories being told in the media and pop culture. In the beginning our
dream was simply of a website where women could share their stories. We
launched with just a handful of stories written by us and our closest
friends and family, and we asked our community to spread our message to the women
in their lives. The message was simple<b> - you have a story to tell, we
believe your story is worthy and important, and we know others will want to
hear it.
As the weeks went by, women from all over the country wrote to us about
loss, addiction, abortions and adoptions, body image, mental illness and even
homelessness. <b>Yet, these stories were not tragic. Instead, they were filled
with courage, humor, survival, hope and redemption.
Our Successes and Strategies
Just 22 weeks after launching, we’ve received
and published nearly 70 stories and had over 26,000 unique page views on our
site.
We believe our success is due to what makes us unique:
<ul>
<li>
We don’t allow comments on
the stories. We want to create the most compassionate and
safe environment possible.
<li>
We are committed to an ad-free
website. Even though advertisements would provide a much
needed revenue stream, ad-free honors the stories and gives them the
space and attention they deserve.
<li>
We encourage all forms of self-expression - music, art, photography, and poetry. Any medium that
women want to use to tell their stories has a home on SpeakYourStory.

column2: ><span>“<i>This site is amazing. I'm going to share a story tomorrow.

column1: Very important gathering place for us to join together in support of women.” ~Susie
Bedsow Horgan
You don’t have to look hard to see examples of
women being marginalized and dehumanized. We live in a world where we use
hashtags to memorialize black women killed by the police, lest we forget their
names. Where 1 in 3 adult women have abortions, yet restrictions to access are
growing in astronomical numbers. Where 1 in 3 women are victims of physical
violence at the hands of their intimate partners. Where 1 in 5 women report
being victims of sexual assault. And, where women are three times more likely
than men to attempt suicide.[1]
We MUST share our stories, reject being silenced and stigmatized
by our experiences, and stand unapologetically in our truths.
By sharing our stories we also break down harmful stereotypes
that have long been used to shame women into silence – fat, ugly, bitch,

slut, bossy, crazy - labels that don’t serve us and certainly don’t define us.

“Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, thank

you for this site.” ~ Manisha Antani

We know
from Google Analytics that men and women are reading our stories in equal
numbers. These
are not women’s issues – these are human issues. We will never have meaningful
social change when 50% of the population are sidelined and silenced.
“I'm not sure I can find the right words. The first story I read was Rachael's and it hit me like a ton of bricks. Not my story, but the
fundamentals of where I am right now are the same. I read all of them after
that. You've caught the tail of something very powerful...<b>From a male perspective, I think I, and all men, owe it to ourselves
and the world (indeed, possibly to the survival or our species), to read and
listen deeply.”    ~ Ben Beck-Coon
Our Next Steps &

column4:
>Meet The Founders

Hi Indiegogo Community! We’re Teal Cracraft and Katie Morris, co-founders of www.SpeakYourStory.org. We’re both Indiana natives who left home for big cities and law degrees. For a while, we lived those dreams - Katie practicing criminal law in Philadelphia and Teal practicing employment law in Newport Beach. Eventually though, we both moved back to Indiana to be closer to family and serendipitously met through a mutual friend. For the last 5 years, we’ve both pursued careers outside the courtroom - Katie in grants and contracts and Teal in sales and business development. About 9 months ago, over lunch at a highly disinteresting CLE, we shared our dreams to create something bigger than ourselves, and the idea for SpeakYourStory was born. We are both passionate advocates for women’s full take down of the patriarchy and all its insidious ways, and we fervently believe SpeakYourStory is an important tool for this work.

Thank you for supporting our campaign! The foundation of SpeakYourStory is our fierce and compassionate community - we are so glad you're joining us!

","There
is nothing more empowering than speaking up for yourself. SpeakYourStory was
founded on the belief that when you tell your story, not only do you discover
your own strength, but you encourage others to find their voice and stories as

well. We are passionately committed to telling the unfiltered, unedited stories of real women. We've already created an online platform to share these stories, and our success in such a short period of time has led us to dream even bigger. Our project has been completely self-funded from the beginning,  and this campaign is the next step to bring these stories to life. We are raising money for the first book in a SpeakYourStory Anthology and a 6-episode Podcast series. Story-telling plays an integral role in fighting and overcoming the forces that have marginalized and
dehumanized women throughout history. With your help we will bring the
authentic, beautiful, transformative stories of women into lives all over the
world.
What We’ve Created So Farwww.SpeakYourStory.org began as a defiant response to the lack of authentic, real
women’s stories being told in the media and pop culture. In the beginning our
dream was simply of a website where women could share their stories. We
launched with just a handful of stories written by us and our closest
friends and family, and we asked our community to spread our message to the women
in their lives. The message was simple - you have a story to tell, we
believe your story is worthy and important, and we know others will want to
hear it.
As the weeks went by, women from all over the country wrote to us about
loss, addiction, abortions and adoptions, body image, mental illness and even
homelessness. Yet, these stories were not tragic. Instead, they were filled
with courage, humor, survival, hope and redemption.
Our Successes and Strategies
Just 22 weeks after launching, we’ve received
and published nearly 70 stories and had over 26,000 unique page views on our
site.
We believe our success is due to what makes us unique:
We don’t allow comments on
the stories. We want to create the most compassionate and
safe environment possible.
We are committed to an ad-free
website. Even though advertisements would provide a much
needed revenue stream, ad-free honors the stories and gives them the
space and attention they deserve.
We encourage all forms of self-expression - music, art, photography, and poetry. Any medium that
women want to use to tell their stories has a home on SpeakYourStory.
“This site is amazing. I'm going to share a story tomorrow.
Very important gathering place for us to join together in support of women.” ~Susie
Bedsow HorganWhy We NEED to Keep Going
You don’t have to look hard to see examples of
women being marginalized and dehumanized. We live in a world where we use
hashtags to memorialize black women killed by the police, lest we forget their
names. Where 1 in 3 adult women have abortions, yet restrictions to access are
growing in astronomical numbers. Where 1 in 3 women are victims of physical
violence at the hands of their intimate partners. Where 1 in 5 women report
being victims of sexual assault. And, where women are three times more likely
than men to attempt suicide.[1]
We MUST share our stories, reject being silenced and stigmatized
by our experiences, and stand unapologetically in our truths.
By sharing our stories we also break down harmful stereotypes
that have long been used to shame women into silence – fat, ugly, bitch,
slut, bossy, crazy - labels that don’t serve us and certainly don’t define us.“Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, thank
you for this site.” ~ Manisha AntaniWe know
from Google Analytics that men and women are reading our stories in equal
numbers. These
are not women’s issues – these are human issues. We will never have meaningful
social change when 50% of the population are sidelined and silenced.
“I'm not sure I can find the right words. The first story I read was Rachael's and it hit me like a ton of bricks. Not my story, but the
fundamentals of where I am right now are the same. I read all of them after
that. You've caught the tail of something very powerful...From a male perspective, I think I, and all men, owe it to ourselves
and the world (indeed, possibly to the survival or our species), to read and
listen deeply.”    ~ Ben Beck-Coon
Our Next Steps & What Your Contributions Will Support
SpeakYourStory Anthology  - a collection of
creative, beautiful, hard-cover books curated on specific themes with written
stories, photography and illustrations that express the same hope, triumph and
redemption as the stories on our website.
We’ll need to raise enough funds to cover the following expenses:
Gathering the stories - we want
our books to represent women from all walks of life and backgrounds - we plan to include women that may not have access to a computer and the
internet which means that we’ll need to gather those stories ourselves. We
estimate that time, travel expenses and outreach will cost $2,000

TOTAL COST: $5,500

stories told live by women of all backgrounds and dive deeper into

such as social justice, relationships, and mental health with our
story-tellers, experts and innovative thinkers on each topic.

Short Summary
Hello! My name is Dale Asis. I'm the Founder and President of the Bayanihan Foundation
Worldwide.<span>  In Tagalog, “bayanihan”

means the spirit of community and cooperation that enables people to reach a common goal. 

In 2008, I went back to my mother’s small village in Labo,
Camarines Norte in the Philippines. I bet you wouldn’t find it on the map of
the Philippines, which has over 7,000 islands. I was struck by the extreme poverty of
my own relatives. My cousin earns less than $2 a day patching used tires.
Many of my relatives wanted to curl up inside my luggage and come to the US with me. This
was a turning point in my life.  I
saw the connection between their desperation and the overwhelming number of people who feel they must
migrate to seek a better life.  I just had to do something. So that same year, I sent money from the US so my
cousin’s son Vicente could go to school.<span>  Eventually
he graduated from college and is now a nurse helping his family

back in Bicol. I changed Vicente's life. I changed his world.

That became my first act of philanthropy. I made a difference in one person’s life. Small changes lead to large results.  In 2010, I established the
Bayanihan Foundation Worldwide to encourage more Filipinos and others living away from their native lands to make a
difference in people’s lives back home.

In late 2014 I committed to helping three young Filipino-Americans visit their families' homeland as part of a NEXTGEN Fellowship, supported by the Bayanihan Foundation, which organized the trip and paid for their travel expenses. I designed our two-week journey to encourage these young men and women to learn more about their origins, become more involved in creating change, and help those still living in the Philippines. In July 2015, along with members
column2: >of the Kaluluwa Collective, we helped restore mangrove barriers, taught students about environmental
column3: > issues, helped clean up village waterways, and shared meals with our new friends. Our trip demonstrated that small changes could lead to large results.
column5: >While there, I witnessed these young people truly engage with their Filipino heritage
column6: they saw what I had seen many years before, and they were moved by it. The projects we participated were all long-term and
column7: > sustainable, designed to improve the lives of native Filipinos and give them the resources to continue them. I want to build on this energy to create ties between Filipinos living abroad and those still living in the Philippines, strengthening both in the process.

column1: NEXTGEN Fellowship is dear to my heart. It speaks to the core of why I was drawn to
help back in the Philippines.  I believe
that if you give people the right opportunity and motivation to help, they can make many small, personal changes that ultimately benefit large
column2: > numbers of people who need help.

column1:
That's why I’m doing this work. 

I'm asking you to donate so that young Filipino Americans can have opportunities to reconnect with their culture and heritage, learn the importance of ""reaching back"" to help others, and gain a larger sense of their responsibilities in the world. Through NEXTGEN they will learn about the foundation’s sustainable projects and learn

to develop their own potential sustainable projects.  Your contribution will enable us to bring more and more of the next generation of Filipinos back to the Philippines, where they will continue these projects. 

I have made a substantial personal commitment to this work, and the Foundation is a recognized 501 c 3 organization, meaning your contribution is tax deductible to the extent permitted by law. Your contribution of  $10, $100, $1000, or whatever you can afford will enable us to recruit the next generation of Filipino Americans in the cause of cultural, spiritual, environmental, and economic renewal for everyone involved. I believe that small changes lead to large results and that when you change someone's world, you change the world.
What We Need &

Our NEXTGEN journeys are designed to put us in close contact with the people of the Philippines. We stayed and ate with families where possible and kept all our expenses to a minimum. That sometimes meant sharing a floor and not having running water!  

But traveling halfway around the world is not cheap. The Bayanihan Foundation needs $2,500 to help pay for trip
expenses, primarily international airfare costs, food, lodging, local van
travel, travel insurance, guides and service project costs. This is a small price to pay for supporting long-term, sustainable efforts to change people's lives for the better.
I invite you to be part of
this change and would also like to offer you some temptations to donate:
For $25, receive one bag of
Philippine dried mangoes
For $50 – receive one box of
Philippine mangoes dipped in chocolate
For $100 – receive one “Tubao,” a
hand-woven unisex scarf of 100% hand-washable cotton (one piece)
For $250 – receive one “Malong,” a traditional
tube skirt"" made of hand-woven multi-colored 100% cotton, bearing a
variety of geometric designs- very versatile could be worn a skirt, as a
beach-cover up, a colorful table accent or as a bed cover
For $500 – receive one bamboo ""good luck"" plant and all four items listed above.
The foundation will use all
funds raised for the expenses of the NEXTGEN Fellowship program
and to ensure the continuation of the program for years to come.
The Impact
Your donation will ensure that the NEXTGEN Fellowship will continue beyond its first year and contribute to the success of the many other

projects of the Bayanihan Foundation:

NextGen Youth
Leadership Development
<li>
$25 will contribute to
a pooled fund, which will be used to support of the NextGen youth
leadership program expenses for one workshop training
<li>
$50 will contribute to
a pooled fund, which will be used to support of the NextGen youth
leadership program expenses for half day of workshops, training,
and site visit
<li>
$100 will contribute to the NextGEN youth leadership program expenses for one full day of workshops, training and site visit
<li>
$250 will contribute to the NextGEN youth leadership program to plant 1,000 mangrove trees, contribute books to a library and fund a giving circle
Your contributions could also help the Bayanihan Foundation's four other efforts: 1) long-term recovery efforts after super typhoon Haiyan
column3: 3) advocacy for the clean-up of former US bases in Clark and Subic
column4:
4) climate change and youth education and training in Cebu. Help us change a world and you also change the world.

Risks &

column1: I see three major risks and challenges to this campaign:
1)  Apathy – potential donors might not think that they can make a
difference and their $25 donation or any amount will not make a difference.
2)  Lack of impact – potential donors might think that their contribution of
$50 or any amount will really not make any impact.
3)  Lack of transparency – potential donors might think that their contribution
will not go towards their intended donation.
I assure you that your funds donated will go towards the NEXTGEN
Fellowship and the long-term sustainable projects of the Bayanihan
Foundation.<span>  Any amount you contribute
will make a difference – large or small. I believe that your donation could be the
change we want to see in this world.  And
I hope that reading this will motivate you to donate. Thank you.
Other Ways You Can Help
You can also help in other ways besides making a financial contribution.
You can do any or all of the following suggestions to change a world and change the world:
1.  Like us and Share on Facebook and social media. Use the Indiegogo share
tools.
2.  Follow the blog at www.fdnbayanihan.org
3.  Tell your friends and family about this campaign and the Bayanihan
Foundation
4.  Attend one of the following three campaign events planned in Chicago, IL and
in Los Angeles, CA: a) Saturday August 29, 2015 - NEXTGEN &amp
column2: Kaluluwa Kolectivo report back Saturday August 29, 2015 - 2 PM till 5 PM at DePaul University 2320 N. Kenmore Ave. Room 280 Chicago: b) Sunday September 27, 2015 – luncheon house party at the

column1: home of Dale Asis’ mother, 3752 N. Central Park Ave. Chicago. Enjoy a home-cooked Filipino meal
column2: and c) October 2015 – final campaign send off in

column1: Los Angeles, CA (date and details to be confirmed)
I invite you to donate and be part of this campaign I’m passionate
about.<span>  Your contribution will change
these young people’s lives but will also change the world. Thank you for your
contribution!

- Versione ITALIANA in fondo - Versión ESPAÑOLA en el fondo - Versão BRASILEIRA na parte inferior -

(IN)Visible is an inspiring documentary about the desaparesido's families who endlessly search for clues. The italian film project has been researched, investigated, produced and directed by Alice Montorselli.

Their passion to give a voice to people who doesn't have one brought them to use her academic credentials and professional expertise as audio-visual experts to create an opportunity for those who do not have one to disseminate the required information about such a theme.

The documentary is about the STRENGTH of the PEOPLE who face everyday struggle and dilemma for missing their LOVED ones under mysterious circumstances wherein human rights are violated unabated! The main case analysed and documented is the story of Martha Escobar.
It is a documentary based on a true story that aims to show the strength of the human being under those type of circumstances.
Who does not understand the suffering, agony and pain when a loved one vanishes all of a sudden?

If such is the case with a friend, partner or family member the shock and mental agony to face such a situation is an unbearable, unsurmountable struggle that a lot of people can imagine but only those who experience it, knows the reality. The pain and suffering is greater when the family members of the missing people do not have even the right to mourn over the sudden disappearance of their loved ones , and instead they are forced to live in the constant hope of new leads and answers that could possibly lead them to getting valid explanations or understanding of what really happened.
Now, try to imagine if something so terrible would happen to you! That someone very close and so loved, suddenly one day disappeared.

Death is more acceptable, and at one point in time it will allow you to mourn, understand and accept the reality. However, would you have peace with yourself if you do not know the circumstances under which a loved one vanishes without any evidence or understandable reasons?

What would you do without any clues? Moreover how would you feel without any power to investigate? How would you accept one as dead when that is not certain? Would you be able to turn the page and carry on with your life under such circumstances?

If you are still reading, perhaps we touch your heart and you understand that in certain circumstances we will have the same feelings of frustration, anger and restlessness. But we know you will fight and you won't give up searching. Those are exactly the circumstances of Martha Escobar
column2: she did not give up and is still fighting over 27 years along with many others.

column1: The aim of the documentary will not be to focus on the missing people, but to understand the psyche of those who are searching for answers. To feel their pain and frustration in facing their terrible reality. To embrace their strength and their determination to understand what happened to their loved ones, and their continuous endless efforts to achieve success by not giving up.

The aim of this documentary is to experience with these people the psychological and practical conditions of the everyday struggle to find clues. We want to support their courage and endurance and make sure that they do not feel alone in their tireless, endless search of 'those that one day were present and visible and the day after became invisible'.
You can make this possible, and a small contribution from all of you will enable us to give the strength of our combined voice to these people.

Every small donation is vital and a step forward to support these people.  Every time that you share it on a social network or discuss it with someone, you become part of our team: that is right! You will be part of those who can make the difference!
Make a difference with a small donation! Give yourself the opportunity to create the universal ripple effect.
We truly, passionately want to make this movie. So passionate we are that we are ready and willing to live practically out of love and fresh air in order to finish this project.
The USD 17.000 that we set as the goal is the minimum that we need to achieve the realization of the documentary in Ecuador. Less will mean we cannot possibly be able to go.
How would you like to support us in our passionate venture to give voice to those who are groping in the dark to find their own loved ones, but in vain, in the technologically advanced 21st century?
Send us to Ecuador and we will tell you everything about these people who need to be heard.
Thank you!
<div>
- ITALIANO -

(IN)Visible è un emozionante e intenso documentario che racconta le storie delle famiglie dei desaparecidos e delle loro incessanti ricerche. Il progetto del film è stato studiato, prodotto e diretto da Alice Montorselli.
 

Il suo ardente desiderio di dar voce alle persone che non ne hanno l'ha spinta a utilizzare le loro credenziali accademiche e la loro competenza professionale nel campo dell'audiovisivo, per fornire una voce a coloro che non ce l’hanno, l’opportunità di diffondere le informazioni necessarie su tale tema.

Il documentario narra della forza delle persone che quotidianamente affrontano sfide e dilemmi a causa della perdita dei propri cari in circostanze misteriose, dove i diritti umani sono stati violati! Il caso principale analizzato e documentato è la storia di Martha Escobar.
Si tratta di un documentario basato su una storia vera, che vuole dimostrare come in tali circostanze possa emergere la forza dell’essere umano.

column4: >Chi di noi non capirebbe la sofferenza, l'agonia e il dolore della perdita di una persona amata?

column1: Sia esso della famiglia, un amico o un amore, lo shock e il tormento di una tale situazione, rappresenta uno sforzo tremendo e insormontabile, che molti possono immaginare, ma soltanto chi lo vive ne comprende la realtà.
Il dolore e la sofferenza sono maggiori quando i familiari delle persone scomparse non hanno nemmeno il diritto di lutto, di piangere sull'improvvisa scomparsa dei loro cari
column2: invece, sono costretti a vivere nella costante speranza di trovare nuovi indizi e risposte, che potrebbero fornir loro una valida spiegazione o comprensione di cosa sia realmente accaduto.

column1: Ora, provate a immaginare se una cosa così terribile accadesse a voi! Che qualcuno di molto vicino e di amato improvvisamente un giorno scomparisse!
La morte è più facile da accettare e ti consente almeno di piangere, capire e accettare la realtà.
Per contro, riuscireste a essere in pace con voi stessi se non conosceste le circostanze in cui un vostro amato è scomparso, senza lasciare traccia o motivo comprensibile?

Voi che cosa fareste se vi ritrovaste senza alcun indizio? O ancora, come vi sentireste senza alcuna possibilità di fare indagini? Come potreste accettare la morte di qualcuno se non ne aveste l'assoluta certezza? Sareste in grado di voltare pagina e continuare con la vostra vita in tali circostanze?
Probabilmente no.

Se state ancora leggendo, forse abbiamo toccato il vostro cuore e capite che tutti noi, in certe circostanze, proveremmo gli stessi sentimenti di frustrazione, rabbia e inquietudine. Anzi, siamo certe che continuereste a lottare e non smettereste di cercare. Queste sono esattamente le circostanze in cui si è trovata Martha Escobar: lei non si è arresa e sta ancora lottando dopo 27 anni, assieme a molti altri.

Lo scopo di questo documentario non è quello di concentrarsi sulle persone scomparse, ma quello di comprendere la psiche di coloro che sono alla ricerca di risposte. Di percepire la loro sofferenza e frustrazione in queste terribili realtà. Di abbracciare la loro forza e la loro determinazione nel capire ciò che è successo ai loro cari, e i loro continui sforzi per raggiungere la verità, senza mai mollare.

Lo scopo di questo documentario è di vivere con queste persone, le condizioni psicologiche e pratiche che si provano durante le lotte quotidiane alla ricerca di qualche traccia. Vogliamo sostenere il loro coraggio e la loro resistenza
column2: vogliamo assicurarci che non si sentano soli nella loro instancabile e incessante ricerca di coloro che un giorno erano presenti e visibili e il giorno dopo sono diventati invisibili.

column1: Potete rendere tutto questo possibile
column2: un piccolo contributo da tutti voi ci permetterà di donare a queste persone la forza delle nostre voci congiunte.

column1: Ogni piccola donazione è vitale e rappresenta un passo avanti per sostenere queste persone.

Ogni volta che condividerete questa campagna su un social network o ne parlerete con qualcuno, entrerete a far parte della nostra squadra. Proprio così! Farete parte di coloro che possono fare la differenza!
Fate la differenza con una piccola donazione! Cogliete l'opportunità di innescare una reazione a catena.

Desideriamo veramente, ardentemente, appassionatamente, fare questo film. Così tanto, che siamo disposte ad andare anche mangiando pane, acqua e cipolle ogni giorno. Anzi, tagliamo anche sulle cipolle! Troppo costose

Scherzi a parte, i 17.000 USD (15.000 €), che ci siamo posti come obiettivo,è la cifra minima che dobbiamo raggiungere per la realizzazione del documentario in Ecuador. Di meno significherebbe non poter andare.
In questo 21° secolo così tecnologicamente avanzato, come vorreste sostenerci nella nostra impresa per dare voce a coloro che brancolano nel buio nel trovare i propri amati?
Permetteteci di andare in Ecuador e vi racconteremo tutto su queste persone, che hanno bisogno di essere ascoltate.
Grazie!
pics Examples

- ESPAÑOL -

 

(IN) visible es un documental inspirador acerca de los familiares de desaparecidos y su búsqueda interminable por pistas que los ayuden a encontrarlos. Este proyecto cinematográfico italiano ha sido investigado, producido y dirigido por Alice Montorselli.

Su pasión por dar voz a la gente que no la tiene, la llevó a utilizar su credenciales académicas y su experiencia profesional como experta audio-visuales para crear una oportunidad para aquellos que no la tienen, para esparcir la información que un tema así requiere.

¡El documental trata acerca de la fuerza de la gente que diariamente enfrenta el dilema y la lucha diaria de perder a sus seres queridos bajo circunstancias misteriosas donde sus derechos humanos fueron violentados sin cesar! El caso analizado y documentado es la historia de Marta Escobar.
Este documental está basado en una historia real y tiene como propósito mostrar la fortaleza del ser humano cuando atraviesa este tipo de circunstancias.
¿Quién no entiende el sufrimiento, agonía y dolor cuando un ser amado desaparece de pronto?

Si ese fuese el caso de un amigo, pareja o un miembro de la familia, el shock y la agonía mental para enfrentar una situación así sería una lucha insoportable, insuperable, que mucha gente puede imaginar pero solo aquellos que lo han experimentado conocen la realidad. El dolor y el sufrimiento es mayor cuando los miembros de la familia del desaparecido no tienen el derecho de estar de luto por su ser querido. Al contrario, ellos son forzados a vivir en la esperanza constante de tener nuevas pistas y respuestas que puedan llevarlos a conseguir explicaciones válidas o entender que es lo que verdaderamente sucedió.
Ahora, intenta imaginar si algo tan terrible te pasaría a ti! Que alguien muy cercano y muy amado de pronto un día desaparece.

La muerte es más aceptable, y llega un punto en el tiempo que te permite estar de luto, entender y aceptar la realidad. Sin embargo, ¿podrías tener paz contigo mismo si tú no sabes las circunstancias bajo las cuales tu ser amado desapareció sin ningún rastro o ninguna razón comprensible?

¿Qué es lo que tú harías sin una sola pista? Más aún, cómo te sentirías sin poder alguno para investigar? ¿Cómo aceptarías que alguien está muerto cuando tú no tienes la certeza? ¿Podrías virar la página y continuar con tu vida bajo estas circunstancias?

Si tú aún estás leyendo esto, talvez nosotras tocamos tu corazón y tú entiendes que bajo ciertas circunstancias nosotros tendríamos los mismos sentimientos de frustración, ira e intranquilidad. Pero nosotros sabemos que tú lucharías y que no pararías de buscar. Esas exactamente fueron las circunstancias para Marta Escobar, ella no se rinde y aún continúa luchando por más de 27 años junto con muchos otros.

El propósito de este documental no está enfocado en los desaparecidos, pero busca entender la psicología de aquellos que buscan por respuestas. Para sentir su dolor y frustración enfrentando esta terrible realidad. Para adoptar su fuerza y su determinación para entender qué pasó con sus seres queridos y con sus continuos e interminables esfuerzos para alcanzar el éxito sin darse por vencidos.

El propósito de este documental es experimentar con estas personas las condiciones psicológicas y prácticas de la lucha diaria por encontrar pistas. Nosotras queremos apoyar su coraje y su resistencia y asegurar que ellos no se sientan solos en su incansable e interminable búsqueda por ‘aquellos que un día estuvieron presentes y fueron visibles y al siguiente día se volvieron invisibles’
Tú puedes hacer esto posible, y una contribución pequeña de todos ustedes nos permitirá dar la fuerza de nuestra voz combinada para estas personas.

Cada pequeña donación es vital y un paso adelante para apoyar a estas personas. Cada vez que tú compartes esto en una red social o discutes esto con alguien, tú te vuelves parte de nuestro grupo: ¡esto es correcto! ¡Tú serás parte de aquellos que pueden hacer la diferencia!
¡Haz la diferencia con una pequeña donación! Date la oportunidad de crear un efecto dominó.

Nosotras verdaderamente, apasionadamente queremos hacer esta película. Estamos tan apasionadas que nosotras estamos listas y dispuestas a vivir a pan y agua si es necesario por finalizar este proyecto!
Los 17.000 USD que colocamos como meta es el mínimo que necesitamos alcanzar para la realización de este documental en Ecuador. Menos de esto, significa que no sería posible ir.

Cómo te gustaría aportar en esta apasionada aventura para dar voz a aquellos que están buscando a tientas en la oscuridad para buscar a sus seres amados, pero en vano, en el tecnológicamente avanzado siglo 21?
Envíanos a Ecuador y nosotros te diremos todo acerca de estas personas que necesitan ser escuchadas.
¡Gracias!
- BRASILEIRO -

(IN)Visible é um documentario inspirador sobre as familias de pessoas desaparecidas que nao desistem de buscar por pistas e rastros. O projeto do filme italiano foi pesquisado, investigado, produzido e dirigido por Alice Montorselli.

O desejo ardente de dar voz a aqueles que nao tem uma foi o que impulsionou ela a utilizar de seu artificios como profissinais do audio-visual para criar uma oportunidade para contarem e compartilharem informacoes sobre o que se passa por tras de tal tema.

O objetivo do documentario é narrar a força das pessoas que se encontram na luta do dia-dia para afrontar os dilemas e as causas da perda de seus entes queridos em circunstancias misteriosas, onde os direitos humanos foram violados! O caso analisado e documentado é a historia de Martha Escobar.
Se trata de um documentario baseado em uma historia real, onde demonstra como o ser humano é capaz de criar forças mesmo estando sob tais cirscunstancias.
A HISTORIA
Quem de nos nao seria capaz de entender a sofrencia, a agonia e a dor da perda de uma pessoa amada?

Seja essa uma pessoa da familia, um amigo querido, um amor. O choque e a tormenta de tal situacao, representa um esforco temendo e imensuravel, que muitos podem imaginar, mas somente alguns vivem e coomprendem a realidade.
A dor e a sofrencia sao maiores quando os familiares da pessoa desaparecida nao possuem ao menos o direito de luto, de lamentar a perda repentina de seu ente querido
column2: invez disso, sao obrigadas a viver com a constante esperança de achar novos indicios ou respostas, que possam dar a elas uma vàlida explicaçao ou coomprensao do que realmente aconteceu.

column1: Agora, tente imaginar se uma coisa terrivel dessas acontecesse com voce! Que qualquer um, muito proximo e querido, de repente, de um dia para o outro, desaparecesse!

A morte é mais facil de aceitar e se se tem ao menos o direito de lamentar, entender e aceitar os fatos. É impossivel conseguir ficar em paz com voce mesmo se nao tiver ao menos o conhecimento ou a condicao na qual um ente querido é dado como desaparecido
column2: sem deixar rastros ou um motivo no minimo coompreensivel.

column1: O que faria se se encontrasse sem algum indicio? Ou até, come se sentiria sem alguma possibilidade de fazer uma investigacao? Como poderia aceitar a morte de qualquer um se nao tivesse a absoluta certeza que de fato é morto? Seria capaz de virar a pagina e continuar a sua vida sob tal situacao?
Pravavelmente nao.

Se voce ainda esta lendo, talvez tenhamos tocado o seu coracao e entende que todos nos, sob tais circunstacias, teriamos os mesmos sentimentos de raiva, frustacao, inquietude. Estamos certos que continuaria a lutar e a nao iria parar de procurar e buscar por pistas. Essas sao as condicoes que se encontra Martha Escobar: ela nao ainda nao desistiu e ainda esta lutando, mesmo apos 27 anos, junto com muitos outros.

O objetivo desse documentario nao é se concentrar nas pessoas desaparecidas, mas sim naquelas que ficam e estudar a sua psique que estao a procura de respostas. De sentir a dor e a frustacao dessa terrivel realidade. De abracar a sua forca e a sua determinacao de entender o que aconteceu a seus entes queridos e o esforco continuo para alcancar a verdade, sem desistir.

Esse documentario mostra a vivencia com essas pessoas, a condicao psicologica e pratica na qual se encontram durante a luta cotidiana atras de qualquer tracos ou rastros que os desaparecidos possam ter deixado. Queremos apoiar a sua coragem e a sua resistencia. Queremos assegurar que nao se sintam sozinhas na sua incansavel e incessante busca daqueles que um dia ja foram presentes e visivies e que no dia seguinte se tornam invisiveis.
Voce pode fazer tudo isso possivel
column2: uma pequena contribuicao de todos voces permitirà a doar a essas pessoas a forca de nossas vozes juntas!

column1: Cada pequena doacao é vital e representa un passo a frente para apoiar essas pessoas.
A cada vez que compartilhar essa campanha em uma rede social ou comentar com alguem, estara fazendo parte da nossa equipe. É isso ai! Voce farà parte daqueles que podem fazer a diferença!
Faça a diferenca com uma pequena doaçao. Agarrem a oportunidade de começar uma reacao em cadeia.

Desejamos veramente, ardentemente, apaixonadamente, fazer esse filme. Tanto que estamos dispostas a irviver somente de pao e agua todos os dias para fazer isso possivel. Viva um dia como nos! Vale a pena :)

piadas a parte, os 17,000 USD (15.000€), que estamos como objetivo, é a quantia minima que devemos juntar para poder realizar o documentario no Equador. Menos que isso, significa nao poder realizar o filme.
Como voce gostaria de apoiar a nossa apaixonante emboscada para dar voz aqueles que vagam no escuro em busca de seus amados perdidos?
Nos permita viajar ao Equador e te contaremos tudo sobre essas pessoas, que precisam ser escutadas
OBRIGADO!

","- Versione ITALIANA in fondo - Versión ESPAÑOLA en el fondo - Versão BRASILEIRA na parte inferior -(IN)Visible is an inspiring documentary about the desaparesido's families who endlessly search for clues. The italian film project has been researched, investigated, produced and directed by Alice Montorselli.Their passion to give a voice to people who doesn't have one brought them to use her academic credentials and professional expertise as audio-visual experts to create an opportunity for those who do not have one to disseminate the required information about such a theme.

The documentary is about the STRENGTH of the PEOPLE who face everyday struggle and dilemma for missing their LOVED ones under mysterious circumstances wherein human rights are violated unabated! The main case analysed and documented is the story of Martha Escobar.
It is a documentary based on a true story that aims to show the strength of the human being under those type of circumstances.
Who does not understand the suffering, agony and pain when a loved one vanishes all of a sudden?

If such is the case with a friend, partner or family member the shock and mental agony to face such a situation is an unbearable, unsurmountable struggle that a lot of people can imagine but only those who experience it, knows the reality. The pain and suffering is greater when the family members of the missing people do not have even the right to mourn over the sudden disappearance of their loved ones , and instead they are forced to live in the constant hope of new leads and answers that could possibly lead them to getting valid explanations or understanding of what really happened.
Now, try to imagine if something so terrible would happen to you! That someone very close and so loved, suddenly one day disappeared.

Death is more acceptable, and at one point in time it will allow you to mourn, understand and accept the reality. However, would you have peace with yourself if you do not know the circumstances under which a loved one vanishes without any evidence or understandable reasons?

What would you do without any clues? Moreover how would you feel without any power to investigate? How would you accept one as dead when that is not certain? Would you be able to turn the page and carry on with your life under such circumstances?

If you are still reading, perhaps we touch your heart and you understand that in certain circumstances we will have the same feelings of frustration, anger and restlessness. But we know you will fight and you won't give up searching. Those are exactly the circumstances of Martha Escobar
column2: she did not give up and is still fighting over 27 years along with many others.

column1: The aim of the documentary will not be to focus on the missing people, but to understand the psyche of those who are searching for answers. To feel their pain and frustration in facing their terrible reality. To embrace their strength and their determination to understand what happened to their loved ones, and their continuous endless efforts to achieve success by not giving up.

The aim of this documentary is to experience with these people the psychological and practical conditions of the everyday struggle to find clues. We want to support their courage and endurance and make sure that they do not feel alone in their tireless, endless search of 'those that one day were present and visible and the day after became invisible'.
You can make this possible, and a small contribution from all of you will enable us to give the strength of our combined voice to these people.

Every small donation is vital and a step forward to support these people.  Every time that you share it on a social network or discuss it with someone, you become part of our team: that is right! You will be part of those who can make the difference!
Make a difference with a small donation! Give yourself the opportunity to create the universal ripple effect.
We truly, passionately want to make this movie. So passionate we are that we are ready and willing to live practically out of love and fresh air in order to finish this project.
The USD 17.000 that we set as the goal is the minimum that we need to achieve the realization of the documentary in Ecuador. Less will mean we cannot possibly be able to go.
How would you like to support us in our passionate venture to give voice to those who are groping in the dark to find their own loved ones, but in vain, in the technologically advanced 21st century?
Send us to Ecuador and we will tell you everything about these people who need to be heard.
Thank you!
- ITALIANO -
