Esas exactamente fueron las circunstancias para Marta Escobar, ella no se rinde y aún continúa luchando por más de 27 años junto con muchos otros.

El propósito de este documental no está enfocado en los desaparecidos, pero busca entender la psicología de aquellos que buscan por respuestas. Para sentir su dolor y frustración enfrentando esta terrible realidad. Para adoptar su fuerza y su determinación para entender qué pasó con sus seres queridos y con sus continuos e interminables esfuerzos para alcanzar el éxito sin darse por vencidos.

El propósito de este documental es experimentar con estas personas las condiciones psicológicas y prácticas de la lucha diaria por encontrar pistas. Nosotras queremos apoyar su coraje y su resistencia y asegurar que ellos no se sientan solos en su incansable e interminable búsqueda por ‘aquellos que un día estuvieron presentes y fueron visibles y al siguiente día se volvieron invisibles’
Tú puedes hacer esto posible, y una contribución pequeña de todos ustedes nos permitirá dar la fuerza de nuestra voz combinada para estas personas.

Cada pequeña donación es vital y un paso adelante para apoyar a estas personas. Cada vez que tú compartes esto en una red social o discutes esto con alguien, tú te vuelves parte de nuestro grupo: ¡esto es correcto! ¡Tú serás parte de aquellos que pueden hacer la diferencia!
¡Haz la diferencia con una pequeña donación! Date la oportunidad de crear un efecto dominó.

Nosotras verdaderamente, apasionadamente queremos hacer esta película. Estamos tan apasionadas que nosotras estamos listas y dispuestas a vivir a pan y agua si es necesario por finalizar este proyecto!
Los 17.000 USD que colocamos como meta es el mínimo que necesitamos alcanzar para la realización de este documental en Ecuador. Menos de esto, significa que no sería posible ir.

Cómo te gustaría aportar en esta apasionada aventura para dar voz a aquellos que están buscando a tientas en la oscuridad para buscar a sus seres amados, pero en vano, en el tecnológicamente avanzado siglo 21?
Envíanos a Ecuador y nosotros te diremos todo acerca de estas personas que necesitan ser escuchadas.
¡Gracias!
- BRASILEIRO -

(IN)Visible é um documentario inspirador sobre as familias de pessoas desaparecidas que nao desistem de buscar por pistas e rastros. O projeto do filme italiano foi pesquisado, investigado, produzido e dirigido por Alice Montorselli.

O desejo ardente de dar voz a aqueles que nao tem uma foi o que impulsionou ela a utilizar de seu artificios como profissinais do audio-visual para criar uma oportunidade para contarem e compartilharem informacoes sobre o que se passa por tras de tal tema.

O objetivo do documentario é narrar a força das pessoas que se encontram na luta do dia-dia para afrontar os dilemas e as causas da perda de seus entes queridos em circunstancias misteriosas, onde os direitos humanos foram violados! O caso analisado e documentado é a historia de Martha Escobar.
Se trata de um documentario baseado em uma historia real, onde demonstra como o ser humano é capaz de criar forças mesmo estando sob tais cirscunstancias.
A HISTORIA
Quem de nos nao seria capaz de entender a sofrencia, a agonia e a dor da perda de uma pessoa amada?

Seja essa uma pessoa da familia, um amigo querido, um amor. O choque e a tormenta de tal situacao, representa um esforco temendo e imensuravel, que muitos podem imaginar, mas somente alguns vivem e coomprendem a realidade.
A dor e a sofrencia sao maiores quando os familiares da pessoa desaparecida nao possuem ao menos o direito de luto, de lamentar a perda repentina de seu ente querido
column2: invez disso, sao obrigadas a viver com a constante esperança de achar novos indicios ou respostas, que possam dar a elas uma vàlida explicaçao ou coomprensao do que realmente aconteceu.

column1: Agora, tente imaginar se uma coisa terrivel dessas acontecesse com voce! Que qualquer um, muito proximo e querido, de repente, de um dia para o outro, desaparecesse!

A morte é mais facil de aceitar e se se tem ao menos o direito de lamentar, entender e aceitar os fatos. É impossivel conseguir ficar em paz com voce mesmo se nao tiver ao menos o conhecimento ou a condicao na qual um ente querido é dado como desaparecido
column2: sem deixar rastros ou um motivo no minimo coompreensivel.

column1: O que faria se se encontrasse sem algum indicio? Ou até, come se sentiria sem alguma possibilidade de fazer uma investigacao? Como poderia aceitar a morte de qualquer um se nao tivesse a absoluta certeza que de fato é morto? Seria capaz de virar a pagina e continuar a sua vida sob tal situacao?
Pravavelmente nao.

Se voce ainda esta lendo, talvez tenhamos tocado o seu coracao e entende que todos nos, sob tais circunstacias, teriamos os mesmos sentimentos de raiva, frustacao, inquietude. Estamos certos que continuaria a lutar e a nao iria parar de procurar e buscar por pistas. Essas sao as condicoes que se encontra Martha Escobar: ela nao ainda nao desistiu e ainda esta lutando, mesmo apos 27 anos, junto com muitos outros.

O objetivo desse documentario nao é se concentrar nas pessoas desaparecidas, mas sim naquelas que ficam e estudar a sua psique que estao a procura de respostas. De sentir a dor e a frustacao dessa terrivel realidade. De abracar a sua forca e a sua determinacao de entender o que aconteceu a seus entes queridos e o esforco continuo para alcancar a verdade, sem desistir.

Esse documentario mostra a vivencia com essas pessoas, a condicao psicologica e pratica na qual se encontram durante a luta cotidiana atras de qualquer tracos ou rastros que os desaparecidos possam ter deixado. Queremos apoiar a sua coragem e a sua resistencia. Queremos assegurar que nao se sintam sozinhas na sua incansavel e incessante busca daqueles que um dia ja foram presentes e visivies e que no dia seguinte se tornam invisiveis.
Voce pode fazer tudo isso possivel
column2: uma pequena contribuicao de todos voces permitirà a doar a essas pessoas a forca de nossas vozes juntas!

column1: Cada pequena doacao é vital e representa un passo a frente para apoiar essas pessoas.
A cada vez que compartilhar essa campanha em uma rede social ou comentar com alguem, estara fazendo parte da nossa equipe. É isso ai! Voce farà parte daqueles que podem fazer a diferença!
Faça a diferenca com uma pequena doaçao. Agarrem a oportunidade de começar uma reacao em cadeia.

Desejamos veramente, ardentemente, apaixonadamente, fazer esse filme. Tanto que estamos dispostas a irviver somente de pao e agua todos os dias para fazer isso possivel. Viva um dia como nos! Vale a pena :)

piadas a parte, os 17,000 USD (15.000€), que estamos como objetivo, é a quantia minima que devemos juntar para poder realizar o documentario no Equador. Menos que isso, significa nao poder realizar o filme.
Como voce gostaria de apoiar a nossa apaixonante emboscada para dar voz aqueles que vagam no escuro em busca de seus amados perdidos?
Nos permita viajar ao Equador e te contaremos tudo sobre essas pessoas, que precisam ser escutadas
OBRIGADO!",13.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Milano, Italy",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/in-visible--2/pica

I am raising the finishing funds to complete the post production, music licensing and film festival entry fees for my Documentary Film ""Desperately Seeking Daddy!""

In every family a story is playing itself out and all its characters affected for better or for worse…

""Desperately Seeking Daddy"" is a fascinating, bold, and revealing documentary.
Curious about her family heritage and ethnic background, Anna takes an Ancestral Ethnicity DNA Test and to the shock and surprise of everyone involved, the man she thought was her biological father is not her father at all. An intense life changing experience unfolds and is captured as it happens as Anna uncovers the dormant truths and wades through the murky memories of her mothers past which leads her on an almost impossible journey to find her biological father who doesnt no she exists.

Desperately Seeking Daddy is obviously very very personal to me. It's a documentary about my overwhelming search for my birth father. Being a very private person myself it has not been easy to open up and let anyone in, let alone the world. But step by step I'm learning to open up and come to terms with the truth of the matter which is ultimately more important to me than my ego or shame.

With this project I'm hoping to inspire others to find their heritage and maybe also open up and let go of their family secrets. At the end of the day we are all human and through sharing our mistakes and journeys with each other we can all learn something that can make a difference.

About us!

Midlands Antifascists are mobilising to oppose the
White Man March in Liverpool, on Saturday August 15th. We will have 2
minibuses travelling in the morning, one from the West Midlands

(Birmingham), and another from the East Midlands (Leicester).
We are a new volunteer-run organisation based across the Midlands, and have recently become recognised as members of the Anti-Fascist Network (AFN - http://antifascistnetwork.org/). We are currently active in Birmingham, Nottingham, Leicester, Derby, Coventry and Leamington Spa.
<ul>

• We believe in equality for all, and see racism and nationalism as being in total opposition to and poisonous and in total opposition to that cause.
  • We organise vocal opposition to and physical disruption of the activities of racist and Neo-Nazi organisations.
  • Antifascists have been proven to stop the growth of the explicit far-right in its tracks, having 'broken the back' of the National Front in the early 90's.
• We continually raise awareness about the dangers and histories of the far-right, both internationally and in the UK.

With your help, we can mobilise 2 minibus-loads alongside the AFN, to disrupt the 'White Man March', an attempt by two explicitly Neo-Nazi groups to establish themselves, and make moves towards having a more radical, dangerous far-right scene like those seen on the continent.
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
The group behind the
White Man March is called ""National Action"", an explicitly Neo-Nazi
group of youngsters who've done such things as:
<li>
<span style=""background-color: initial

<span style=""background-color: initial

Midlands. The most concerning of these are the openly Neo-Nazi

Misanthropic Division"", an international coalition, whose UK members include some previously involved in ""Combat 18""  (""18"", the number corresponding to the position in the alphabet of the initials ""AH"" for Adolf Hitler). Combat 18 were a UK Neo-Nazi group responsible for fire-bombings and other racially motivated attacks. Misanthropic Division members in the UK have links to:
<li><span style=""background-color: initial

column1: <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
Fascist movements grow
when given the chance to promote themselves and recruit, especially in
times of economic turmoil. Allowing them to march makes them more
brazen, and they see it as a victory, despite always being protected by
legions of police. This bbc2 documentary is a fantastic on the topic (<a href=""http://l.facebook.com/l.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fvimeo.com%2F70310184&amp
In the past year we've seen the Midlands targeted by
racists, because it's been seen as an easy target with a lot of ethnic
and cultural diversity but without any previously established
antifascist groups.

• Muslim owned shops in Birmingham have been attacked after Charlie Hebdo and the attention Europes rulers and media brought to it (i100.independent.co.uk/article/muslimowned-shops-in-birmingham-attacked-with-guns-and-hammers--xym9dNkyox).
• Multiple racist groups demonstrating in Dudley/Solihull.
• University campuses in the region sprayed with swastikas and racist tags targeting both Muslims and Jews.
Neo-nazis across
Eurpose organise White Man Marches and the one in Liverpool is expected
to draw together neo-nazis and white supremacists from across the
country. National Action are hoping this will help them build a more

radical, dangerous European style Neo-Nazi movement in the UK.

What we need

We need donations! We

don't currently have all the money required to hire the minibuses, and we'll need to book them before we've received the money for people booking seats.
ALSO - in case our drivers
can't make it - if you know someone who'd be willing and able to drive a minibus for us, please get in touch!
Other info and ways you can help

To book seats for £10 return (£5 unwaged), email us at midlandsantifascists@riseup.net.
We also need people to get involved! If you are passionate about seeking equality, get in touch and introduce yourself. There are roles for people from all backgrounds, abilities
column2: we even have small roles for people who are incredibly busy!

30,000 Litres is about water privatization in Ireland and the social change movement that has been spurred by this austerity measure. We are bringing global awareness to this issue in order to show others how to protect their human rights and create a better world.

The Synopsis:
30,000 Litres is a full-length documentary about water privatization in Ireland and the human rights movement being led by Irish citizens.

While the United Nations states that every human needs 36,500 litres of water every year just to survive, the Irish government has put new restrictions on water usage, allowing each Irish household access to a free allowance of 30,000 litres of water for the year. After that usage cap is reached, residents face direct charges.

With these restrictions, whispers of scandal have also been echoing throughout the country. Money that was supposed to go towards Ireland’s decaying water infrastructure is unaccounted for, tax dollars from citizens seem to have disappeared, and Irish Water, the company that now manages Ireland’s water infrastructure, has already come under fire for profligate spending of taxpayer money.

Using the human right to water, the Irish have mobilized in a new revolution to stop the endless austerity measures their country has been enduring since the EU bailout. Community organizations, trade unions, and political parties have united to establish the Policy Principles for a Progressive Irish Government (a human rights manifesto). This document addresses 10 human rights claims, including water. The proposal was released to every Irish citizen to amend and will now be the platform of a coming Town Hall Tour in September  2015.

30,000 Litres is a story of social change and will provide living examples of how activism can work outside of politics. The human rights manifesto hitting the streets of Ireland next month will provide a lasting story of how people can work together to overcome injustice. This documentary will also expand outside of Ireland’s borders, shining light on the solidarity movement happening in Greece, the empowering work that’s being done by the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund (CELDF) in the U.S., and a trip to meet with the Detroit Water Brigade (whose members have helped in Ireland's fight against privatizing this precious resource).

With media blackouts and corruption in Ireland seeming to be on the rise, 30,000 Litres helps give these activists a conduit to share their story and provides a model of how positive activism can be implemented locally and globally. Made of some of the toughest sinew and bone, with strong currents of blood running through their veins, the people of Ireland deserve a voice. Let’s tell their stories and chant with them “water is a human right,” a human right that will not be taken away from the Irish.
column4:
/>

via Right2Water Ireland


The Project:
30,000 Litres has an established crew, contacts, and a medium to see this production through. This documentary has been backed by PBS, giving us access to a National audience and non-profit status. On top of a National outlet for the documentary, this content can reach an International audience. Due to the tight deadline, we are looking for funding partners who can meet our timeline. We know that 30,000 Litres is not just another water privatization documentary – we are offering real, grassroots solutions that a mass audience can relate to and use. Water is the one thing that connects every human. If you can't help with funding, then we hope you'll spread the good word and help us share this story with a mass audience.

Why you should care:
There is one catch to all of this lovely activism news: no ONE is covering these social change movements on a mass scale! How many of you are actually aware that the water in Ireland is in the process of being privatized? How many of you have heard of the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund? Everyone should know about these amazing stories of real change, outside of politics. The 30,000 Litres crew wants to bring these uplifting stories about positive social change to a wide audience. We have a kick-ass crew of award-winning filmmakers, fantastic characters, and inspiring stories waiting to be presented to the world.

The Budget:
Seriously: We have our crew, we have our contacts, we did our research. All we need is the financing for the travel and production costs.

The budget for 30,000 Litres is actually $247,000. The $150,000 raised on here will go towards our production, travel, and gear. This is the bare-bones budget we need to make sure this movie happens.

Donation Options:
30,000 Litres has been backed by PBS. This means we have non-profit status and the option for tax deductible donations is available. For those who are interested in using this avenue to contribute to the film, please contact the crew directly at 30000litres@gmail.com and we will follow-up with instructions for donating through PBS.

The Crew:
DR. PHIL HOFFMAN - Executive Producer: Phil is a documentary Producer and General Manager with PBS KMOS station outside of Kansas City, Missouri. He has won multiple Emmy awards for his work on his documentaries Turn Blue: The Short Life of Ghoulardi, Hammer on Steel, and more. Phil is a former News Anchor for Akron’s ABC affiliate, professor for the School of Communications at The University of Akron, and General Manager of The University of Akron’s “ZTV” program.

KATIE YOUNG – Producer / Director: Journalist and independent filmmaker, Katie Young, produced the international award-winning documentary, The Graceful Descent. While she covers stories that effect the environment and human rights, she also builds her life around these convictions. She's an organic gardener, food activist, founder of Edible Kent, and the visionary of Young Blood Productions.

KARA MARTINELLI – Associate Producer: Kara has produced the Emmy award-winning aviation documentary titled The Restorers – They Were All Volunteers, Beyond the Powder: The Legacy of the First Women’s Cross-Country Air Race, a documentary for the Texas Flying Legends Museum, and the short historical aviation film, Rise Above, for the CAF Red Tail Squadron’s traveling exhibit.

She has returned to Cleveland from New York City, where she had worked as a Producer creating spots for Food Network, USA, and Touchstone Energy. Her experience also includes various production work with Comedy Central, HBO, A&
column5:
E, E!, NBC, Bravo, ESPN, PBS Thirteen, and TBS.

ADAM WHITE – Cinematographer: Adam, a graduate of the film program from Wright State University, has won multiple regional Emmy awards for his films The Restorers, Red Tail Reborn, and The Restorers: They Were All Volunteers, and an Emmy for cinematography for the PBS documentary Generations: Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Adam and his company Hemlock Films received the rare “Special Achievement” award from the International Council of Airshows in 2011 for his film Rise Above.

With over 20 years of experience, Adam has worked on most every type of media in various roles. The majority of his time is spent working as a director/cinematographer with a specialty in SteadiCam working on big budget Hollywood films, TV movies, award winning documentaries, and commercials.

ROB NETHERTON - Editor / Animator: Rob edited, animated, and designed the packaging for the award-winning documentary The Graceful Descent. Database guru, programmer, and artist, Rob is blessed with artistic talent and the analytical skills to give films a cohesive look, and to add their final touches.
column7:
/>


Young Blood Productions Company Profile:
Young Blood Productions is the brainchild of Katie Young. This award-winning production company was started in a living room in Akron, Ohio. Our production company maintains a reputation of producing unconventional films that bring environmental, social, and political issues to an international audience.","30,000 Litres is about water privatization in Ireland and the social change movement that has been spurred by this austerity measure. This document addresses 10 human rights claims, including water. The proposal was released to every Irish citizen to amend and will now be the platform of a coming Town Hall Tour in September  2015.30,000 Litres is a story of social change and will provide living examples of how activism can work outside of politics. The human rights manifesto hitting the streets of Ireland next month will provide a lasting story of how people can work together to overcome injustice. This documentary will also expand outside of Ireland’s borders, shining light on the solidarity movement happening in Greece, the empowering work that’s being done by the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund (CELDF) in the U.S., and a trip to meet with the Detroit Water Brigade (whose members have helped in Ireland's fight against privatizing this precious resource).With media blackouts and corruption in Ireland seeming to be on the rise, 30,000 Litres helps give these activists a conduit to share their story and provides a model of how positive activism can be implemented locally and globally. Made of some of the toughest sinew and bone, with strong currents of blood running through their veins, the people of Ireland deserve a voice. Let’s tell their stories and chant with them “water is a human right,” a human right that will not be taken away from the Irish.via Right2Water IrelandThe Project:30,000 Litres has an established crew, contacts, and a medium to see this production through. This documentary has been backed by PBS, giving us access to a National audience and non-profit status. On top of a National outlet for the documentary, this content can reach an International audience. Due to the tight deadline, we are looking for funding partners who can meet our timeline. We know that 30,000 Litres is not just another water privatization documentary – we are offering real, grassroots solutions that a mass audience can relate to and use. Water is the one thing that connects every human. If you can't help with funding, then we hope you'll spread the good word and help us share this story with a mass audience.Why you should care:There is one catch to all of this lovely activism news: no ONE is covering these social change movements on a mass scale! How many of you are actually aware that the water in Ireland is in the process of being privatized? How many of you have heard of the Community Environmental Legal Defense Fund? Everyone should know about these amazing stories of real change, outside of politics. The 30,000 Litres crew wants to bring these uplifting stories about positive social change to a wide audience. We have a kick-ass crew of award-winning filmmakers, fantastic characters, and inspiring stories waiting to be presented to the world.The Budget:Seriously: We have our crew, we have our contacts, we did our research. All we need is the financing for the travel and production costs.The budget for 30,000 Litres is actually $247,000. The $150,000 raised on here will go towards our production, travel, and gear. This is the bare-bones budget we need to make sure this movie happens.Donation Options:30,000 Litres has been backed by PBS. This means we have non-profit status and the option for tax deductible donations is available. For those who are interested in using this avenue to contribute to the film, please contact the crew directly at 30000litres@gmail.com and we will follow-up with instructions for donating through PBS.The Crew:DR. PHIL HOFFMAN - Executive Producer: Phil is a documentary Producer and General Manager with PBS KMOS station outside of Kansas City, Missouri. He has won multiple Emmy awards for his work on his documentaries Turn Blue: The Short Life of Ghoulardi, Hammer on Steel, and more. Phil is a former News Anchor for Akron’s ABC affiliate, professor for the School of Communications at The University of Akron, and General Manager of The University of Akron’s “ZTV” program.KATIE YOUNG – Producer / Director: Journalist and independent filmmaker, Katie Young, produced the international award-winning documentary, The Graceful Descent. While she covers stories that effect the environment and human rights, she also builds her life around these convictions. She's an organic gardener, food activist, founder of Edible Kent, and the visionary of Young Blood Productions.KARA MARTINELLI – Associate Producer: Kara has produced the Emmy award-winning aviation documentary titled The Restorers – They Were All Volunteers, Beyond the Powder: The Legacy of the First Women’s Cross-Country Air Race, a documentary for the Texas Flying Legends Museum, and the short historical aviation film, Rise Above, for the CAF Red Tail Squadron’s traveling exhibit.She has returned to Cleveland from New York City, where she had worked as a Producer creating spots for Food Network, USA, and Touchstone Energy. Her experience also includes various production work with Comedy Central, HBO, A&E, E!, NBC, Bravo, ESPN, PBS Thirteen, and TBS.ADAM WHITE – Cinematographer: Adam, a graduate of the film program from Wright State University, has won multiple regional Emmy awards for his films The Restorers, Red Tail Reborn, and The Restorers: They Were All Volunteers, and an Emmy for cinematography for the PBS documentary Generations: Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Adam and his company Hemlock Films received the rare “Special Achievement” award from the International Council of Airshows in 2011 for his film Rise Above.With over 20 years of experience, Adam has worked on most every type of media in various roles. The majority of his time is spent working as a director/cinematographer with a specialty in SteadiCam working on big budget Hollywood films, TV movies, award winning documentaries, and commercials.ROB NETHERTON - Editor / Animator: Rob edited, animated, and designed the packaging for the award-winning documentary The Graceful Descent. Database guru, programmer, and artist, Rob is blessed with artistic talent and the analytical skills to give films a cohesive look, and to add their final touches. Young Blood Productions Company Profile:Young Blood Productions is the brainchild of Katie Young. This award-winning production company was started in a living room in Akron, Ohio. Our production company maintains a reputation of producing unconventional films that bring environmental, social, and political issues to an international audience.",2.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Summary

Where are you? London, Dallas, Perth, Cape Town, Harare? As a fan of Zimbabwean school sports, you have probably found yourself wishing there was a live broadcast of that exciting match between rival schools or national tournament final. On occasion you have found SSN’s live text commentary or live tweets informative, but there’s nothing better than sitting back, relaxing and watching it yourself.

What We Need

With your help, we at School Sports Network want to bring live streamed school sports matches to you. We have the trained expertise and most of the equipment required to make it all happen.
Reaching our crowdfunding goal will allow us to buy encoders, recorders, software and licensing to bring you high resolution video coverage with live sound on the web.
What you Get
The live streaming service will be available on a pay per view or subscription basis. by helping us meet our goal you will earn a subscription to watch live school sports from Zimbabwe.
column2: >We will start bringing you live events next school term(September 2015) . Sports you can expect to be streamed include cricket(T20), swimming, basketball, volleyball, rugby, track/athletics, field hockey, soccer, rowing and water polo.

column1:
Remember all help doesn't have to be monetary, help us spread the word by sharing this campaign with your networks.

Short Summary

My name is Phillip Johnson, an author, filmmaker, and social entrepreneur. My wife and I launched CMT-TV a non profit film production company as a tool  of empowerment what would  allow local filmmakers to gain experience, while exploring the history of this great city - while getting paid. Our website www.cmt-tv.org lists our film inventory of great St. Louis moments and storylines.

Then came August 9th, 2014 and the shooting of Michael Brown. I recall how great cities burned in the aftermath of the assassination of Dr. King, and the LA Riots that followed the Rodney King verdict. The passionate and angry aftermath of Michael Brown's death awakened both St. Louis and the world to a variety of long standing and unresolved social justice issues.

On my website www.revolutionarymind.net I posted a series of #Ferguson Films, that provided insights and analysis as events unfolded. This is my last Ferguson Film which, will be presented in three vignettes.
1) The Long Fuse to Ferguson - a look at Sylvester Brown's informative blog which tracked events that led to the underlying issues exposed by Michael Brown's tragic death.

2) Fire this Time Captures the movement through the eyes of the protestors and reporters whose narratives included arrest, teargassing, and bearing witness to the unprecendented militarization of urban police. We will also discuss the future of this  movement, and what are it's challenges. Finally, how lives were changed by this movement.

column4: > Will discuss the variety of systems all under white rule whose laws, and processes have a deleterious
column5: > effect on poor people and people of color.

column1: Will allow CMT-TV to support local filmmakers, producers, and artists. Some of the  perks that this campaign will pay for will be books and portraits by local artists. In addition your support will allow CMT-TV to increase it's production values with additional camera and sound equipment. In addition it will help CMT-TV.org meet our commitment to support local filmmakers, as your support will allow us to hire additional production personnel to assure this project is produced in a manner that honors the subject.
To find out more about CMT-TV ( Community Television) go to www.cmt-tv.org
Local Non Profit Organizations like Arch City Defenders, MORE - Missourians for Organizing, Reform and Empowerment, may receive a portion of the funds raised by this campaign.
Spread the word! Find out how you can be a campaign Crowdfunding Producer, by reaching out to friends and family and sharing the project with them.

Will allow CMT-TV to support local filmmakers, producers, and artists. Some of the  perks that this campaign will pay for will be books and portraits by local artists. 33 A.D. : The Year That Changed The World

Hi there! I'm Christian Golden I'm the Creative Director for Light Christian Ministries in Alvin Texas and I'm very excited to be unveiling our new production on the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ.
What started out as just an illustrative sermon with a couple of actors and  a slide show has become a full fledged theater production that takes you back 2000 years to the time of Christ.
With a cast of 40+ and a behind the scenes crew it takes a lot to put on each new production, from sets to lights to animals we need your help to bring the gospel to life in a way never before seen!
The Impact
33 A.D. The Year That Changed The World is a family friendly presentation of the greatest story ever told in it's truest form: Live drama.

Every year families from all over the Houston area come to watch our portrayal of the life of Christ over and over again, each year we write a new script and introduce a new way of telling the story of Jesus from his entry into Jerusalem on a donkey, to his struggle in the garden, to his death on the cross and his resurrection on Easter Sunday!
We do not charge for tickets, every single production we do is completely free of charge because we believe that the gospel of Jesus Christ should be a free gift to each of our guest's

With the production growing bigger and bigger each year we need all of your help to bring the bible to life!  Together with your gift, we can help fulfill the great commission of the Lord Jesus Christ. This is your opportunity to share in advancing the Kingdom of God in an up close and personal way. Thank you in advance for helping us share the greatest stories ever told in a way that will never be forgotten.

As the Apostle Paul told those who gave financial gifts to help him share the gospel, we say to you, ""This service that you perform is not only supplying the needs of God's people but is also overflowing in many expressions of thanks to God. Because of the service by which you have proved yourselves, men will praise God for the obedience that accompanies your confession of the gospel of Christ, and for your generosity in sharing with them and with everyone else. (2 Cor 9:12-14 NIV)

Short Summary

The Polk County Film Initiative is expanding its theme of bringing film production to Polk County by launching the 2015 Tryon International Film Festival. The festival organizers are targeting 3Q 2015 with an array of independent titles which will premiere over a two-day period At multiple venues in and around Tryon, NC. 

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

Your generous donations will help us impact Polk County by bringing this film festival to Tryon, NC. We need  funds for festival operations, equipment and rental costs, permits, software tools, venue rental fees, insurance, food, and other general costs, award materials, collateral material, advertising and marketing, printed materials, travel and lodging for guest speakers.

column1:
The Impact

Our goal is to use this festival as a means to drive tourism and film interest for both viewing and shooting in Polk County.
Risks &

In addition to donating funds, we are also seeking volunteers to help with set-up, break-down, registration, and festival operations. 
Equipment and materials that can also be donated: A/V equipment, speakers, meeting-room projectors for workshops, printing for marketing and festival materials.

The Issues:
22 Veterans commit suicide every day which is
over 8,000 per<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
Veteran divorce rates in most cases are double
the rate of their civilian counterparts. The divorce rate is even higher for
Combat Veterans.
While Veterans only represent 11% of the
population, they represent 28-33% of the homeless population
o
As many as 300,000 Veterans will go homeless or
in a shelter on any given night.
A majority of the civilian population does not
know or understand the issues that are facing Veterans as they return from
combat trying to reintegrate into society.
o
As barriers on what is acceptable to discuss
have been put in place, the ability for civilians to understand the issues are
extremely limited, which lead to further isolation and a larger gap between
Veterans and the civilian population.
The VA is a broken system! While they are making some
progress,  hiring good employees who mean well, they have not been able to
figure these issues out and many will remain the same as they did a century
ago.
Who we are:
The Stain of War is an
organization founded by United States Military Combat Veterans and various
Patriotic Americans who want to do their part facing these issues head on. We
are a New Jersey Non-Profit organization with a simple goal of making a
difference, opening a dialogue, and hopefully changing some statistics for the
better. We aren’t
experts and we don’t claim to have a miracle cure, but our hope is simply
to raise awareness, get people talking about the issues and hopefully finding some
things that work for some people. Our motto is straightforward, if we help one
person, or one family who is struggling, all of the hard work and effort is
worth it.
Our Approach:
Easily put, we want the
people who live this life on a daily basis to share their stories and we want
to get as many people as possible to listen and truly understand the realities
of what they deal with. Our approach is to do “no holds barred”interviews with
Combat Veterans, their families, therapists who specialize in combat PTSD, and
the families of those Veterans who made the ultimate decision to end their
life. The plan is to do this with a feature length documentary, followed by a
recurring web series with in-depth interviews and real life stories. We will
discuss the realities of what our Veterans go through in combat, how these
events will affect them and their families, why it affects them this way, and
what we can do to help. For so long these issues have been off limits and there
have been rules around what can or cannot be discussed. It is our belief that
an open discussion about these issues is the only way to really start finding

solutions. 


Special Perk: $30 Custom Vinyl Unit Sticker - 50 Available


Honor the Unit you served in with this special Perk. 

We'll work together to create the custom logo so you can put it on just about anything. These Vinyl stickers look great on cars but can stick to a lot of surfaces. What's special about Vinyl stickers is they don't have a background. It's the image and that's it. 

Stickers will be 6"" wide by 6"" tall depending on image and available in most colors. 

This special is available for a short time or until supplies run out.
Our Goals:
<ul>
<li>
Remove the stigma that comes from combat PTSD, help Veterans integrate
back into civilian life, help civilians understand the Veteran community, stop
Veteran suicide and get rid of Veteran homelessness.
• While we are not delusional and we aren’t under the impression that by
simply doing a movie and some video interviews that we will solve all of these
problems, we do feel it is important to aim high and hope we help change the
outcome for some people along the way.
<li>
Spread Awareness!
• As we moved forward with this project, we realized how many people just
didn’t know what was going on with this issue. We cannot expect to fix a
problem, unless people are aware there is a problem.
<li>
Let Veterans who may be struggling, or feeling weak because of their
PTSD know that they are NOT alone and that what they are feeling is completely
normal after what they’ve seen and done.
• One of the most common reasons we’ve encountered in Combat Veterans
with suicidal thoughts has been the feeling of isolation, or that they are
alone. Another has been the feeling of weakness when they feel they are
struggling and broken, while the people they served with seem fine on the
outside.
<li>
Show Veterans and the Civilian population that Combat PTSD affects many
people from all walks of life and that Combat PTSD does not need to define you.
• We’ve met Veterans dealing with Combat PTSD who are doctors, lawyers,
fathers, mothers, police officers, college students, professors, and just about
anything else you can think of! PTSD does NOT define who you are, or what you
are able to do in life.
<li>
Inform the civilian population of the realities of combat PTSD and let
them know that contrary to the current opinions, Veterans with Combat PTSD are
not ticking time bombs who should be feared.
• This perception is not only false, but it makes it difficult for
Veterans to find jobs, maintain relationships and build a supportive social
setting.
<ul><li>
Give family members and friends a glimpse of what is going on and why
their Veteran may act a certain way, or react a certain way to different
things.
• Misunderstandings and a Veterans inability to share these feelings or
reactions often lead to distance in between friends and family members. This
can lead to isolation, divorce and a deeper depression over the issue.
<ul><li>
Let Veterans know that it is okay to reach out for help!
• Anyone who joined the military is by nature an independent person. A
person who joined an organization with the intent of helping others! Now that
they need help, it is uncomfortable for them. We want to promote the feeling
that it is alright to reach out for help and at the same time remove the victim
mentality that is so uncomfortable for so many Veterans.
• Empower Veterans, let them know that there is hope for a good future
and share stories of things that worked for other Veterans.
How you can help:
<ul>
• Share our
Facebook page, share our Indiegogo and help us spread awareness!
• Donate to
our cause!! Whether it is $1 or $1,000, every little bit helps!
• Share
your story! If you are a Veteran, a therapist, a friend or family member of a
Veteran, or someone who lost someone to suicide from the effects of Combat
PTSD, we want to hear from you.
• Run a
charity event! Whether it’s a golf tournament, a raffle, or something with your
coworkers, we need your help.
Why we need the money:
We
decided a long time ago that we were going to do this no matter what. If it
meant that we had to do it with no money, in our spare time, with a cheap
camera, we were going to do it, simply because it may help a single person.
That said, the more money we can raise, the better job we can do and the better
the film is, the more people who will watch and the better chance we have of
reaching someone who may need to hear our message. I promise you, we are not in
this to line our own pockets! Everyone working on this project has a full time
job and is able to support themselves and their families. However, much of the

outside support we need is from people who are trying to make a living. We've solidified a partnership with a production company to direct, shoot, and edit the film. This is something we cannot afford anymore ourselves if we want to do it right. Things like camera rentals, lights and audio equipment, studio time, post-production services, etc. can be very expensive on a feature length documentary. When we need a song, or marketing documents, or legal advice, or
something along those lines, we need to pay for it. To date, we have done that
with our own money, but we aren’t rich and this isn’t sustainable.
Another
large, but important cost is travel. For instance, we have a woman right now,
who lost her son to suicide after combat tours. The story of her son and the
pieces he left behind are heartbreaking and powerful and it is a story that
needs to be told! It needs to be told, so another Veteran who may be
contemplating suicide can see that damage it leaves behind! So they can see
that they aren’t alone in their feelings, but that there is a better way.
Unfortunately, she does not live close by, so this involves a film crew
traveling to her. With car rentals, hotels, meals, and other travel expenses it can get very expensive.
math is simple. If we raise no money, we will do what we can locally with what
we have. If we raise a thousand dollars, maybe we can do a little more. If we
raise $20K, we can make something decent and worth watching. If we raise $100K,
we can make a quality movie that will do this cause justice and reach a much,
much larger audience and hopefully help that many more people with their daily
struggle!
The Title:
Many
have asked about the name “The Stain of War”, as it can sound anti-war, or
anti-troop upon initially hearing it. I assure you it is not us saying that
troops are “stained” after combat. When I returned from war, I heard many times
people talk about the stigma that comes with combat PTSD. I heard many talk
about how they couldn’t discuss what they saw and did with their loved ones,
because they did not want to be looked at differently. I’ve heard Combat
Veterans discuss how they felt they have a “stain on their soul” after seeing
what they saw, or doing what they had to do.
One
day, I came across a poem by a gentleman named Lonn Sweeney, called “Who Loves
the Warrior”. After years of seeing people point their fingers at the VA and
everyone else for not doing enough and reading the poem, I decided that it was
us, as fellow Veterans, fellow Warriors, who had to stand up and help to “remove
this stain”. That is where the name comes from and our mission is simply to
remove the Stain of War! Below is Lonn’s Poem.
Who loves the Warrior?
Not those he has fought for, for those he has fought for have seen the stain of
battle on his garment.
They draw back when they learn of the deed he has done to keep them safe.
It is better for them to keep a distance from the warrior so the stain will not
spoil the perception of their dignity.
Yet the warrior continues to give his all.
<em>
He must fight the battles to keep those
souls he loves free from harm and free from the stain of evil, for he is a
warrior, the only shield between good and evil, it is only the warrior who
loves the warrior.
<strong><em><em>

Our Approach:
Easily put, we want the
people who live this life on a daily basis to share their stories and we want
to get as many people as possible to listen and truly understand the realities
of what they deal with. Our approach is to do “no holds barred”interviews with
Combat Veterans, their families, therapists who specialize in combat PTSD, and
the families of those Veterans who made the ultimate decision to end their
life. The plan is to do this with a feature length documentary, followed by a
recurring web series with in-depth interviews and real life stories. We will
discuss the realities of what our Veterans go through in combat, how these
events will affect them and their families, why it affects them this way, and
what we can do to help. For so long these issues have been off limits and there
have been rules around what can or cannot be discussed. It is our belief that
an open discussion about these issues is the only way to really start finding

solutions. Special Perk: $30 Custom Vinyl Unit Sticker - 50 AvailableHonor the Unit you served in with this special Perk. We'll work together to create the custom logo so you can put it on just about anything. These Vinyl stickers look great on cars but can stick to a lot of surfaces. What's special about Vinyl stickers is they don't have a background. It's the image and that's it. Stickers will be 6"" wide by 6"" tall depending on image and available in most colors. This special is available for a short time or until supplies run out.
Our Goals:
Remove the stigma that comes from combat PTSD, help Veterans integrate
back into civilian life, help civilians understand the Veteran community, stop
Veteran suicide and get rid of Veteran homelessness.
While we are not delusional and we aren’t under the impression that by
simply doing a movie and some video interviews that we will solve all of these
problems, we do feel it is important to aim high and hope we help change the
outcome for some people along the way.
Spread Awareness!
As we moved forward with this project, we realized how many people just
didn’t know what was going on with this issue. We cannot expect to fix a
problem, unless people are aware there is a problem.
Let Veterans who may be struggling, or feeling weak because of their
PTSD know that they are NOT alone and that what they are feeling is completely
normal after what they’ve seen and done.
One of the most common reasons we’ve encountered in Combat Veterans
with suicidal thoughts has been the feeling of isolation, or that they are
alone. Another has been the feeling of weakness when they feel they are
struggling and broken, while the people they served with seem fine on the
outside.
Show Veterans and the Civilian population that Combat PTSD affects many
people from all walks of life and that Combat PTSD does not need to define you.
We’ve met Veterans dealing with Combat PTSD who are doctors, lawyers,
fathers, mothers, police officers, college students, professors, and just about
anything else you can think of! PTSD does NOT define who you are, or what you
are able to do in life.
Inform the civilian population of the realities of combat PTSD and let
them know that contrary to the current opinions, Veterans with Combat PTSD are
not ticking time bombs who should be feared.
This perception is not only false, but it makes it difficult for
Veterans to find jobs, maintain relationships and build a supportive social
setting.
Give family members and friends a glimpse of what is going on and why
their Veteran may act a certain way, or react a certain way to different
things.
Misunderstandings and a Veterans inability to share these feelings or
reactions often lead to distance in between friends and family members. This
can lead to isolation, divorce and a deeper depression over the issue.
Let Veterans know that it is okay to reach out for help!
Anyone who joined the military is by nature an independent person. A
person who joined an organization with the intent of helping others! Now that
they need help, it is uncomfortable for them. We want to promote the feeling
that it is alright to reach out for help and at the same time remove the victim
mentality that is so uncomfortable for so many Veterans.
Empower Veterans, let them know that there is hope for a good future
and share stories of things that worked for other Veterans.
How you can help:
Share our
Facebook page, share our Indiegogo and help us spread awareness!
Donate to
our cause!! Whether it is $1 or $1,000, every little bit helps!
Share
your story! If you are a Veteran, a therapist, a friend or family member of a
Veteran, or someone who lost someone to suicide from the effects of Combat
PTSD, we want to hear from you.
Run a
charity event! Whether it’s a golf tournament, a raffle, or something with your
coworkers, we need your help.
Why we need the money:
We
decided a long time ago that we were going to do this no matter what. If it
meant that we had to do it with no money, in our spare time, with a cheap
camera, we were going to do it, simply because it may help a single person.
That said, the more money we can raise, the better job we can do and the better
the film is, the more people who will watch and the better chance we have of
reaching someone who may need to hear our message. I promise you, we are not in
this to line our own pockets! Everyone working on this project has a full time
job and is able to support themselves and their families. However, much of the

outside support we need is from people who are trying to make a living. We've solidified a partnership with a production company to direct, shoot, and edit the film. This is something we cannot afford anymore ourselves if we want to do it right. Things like camera rentals, lights and audio equipment, studio time, post-production services, etc. can be very expensive on a feature length documentary. When we need a song, or marketing documents, or legal advice, or
something along those lines, we need to pay for it. To date, we have done that
with our own money, but we aren’t rich and this isn’t sustainable.
Another
large, but important cost is travel. For instance, we have a woman right now,
who lost her son to suicide after combat tours. The story of her son and the
pieces he left behind are heartbreaking and powerful and it is a story that
needs to be told! It needs to be told, so another Veteran who may be
contemplating suicide can see that damage it leaves behind! So they can see
that they aren’t alone in their feelings, but that there is a better way.
Unfortunately, she does not live close by, so this involves a film crew
traveling to her. With car rentals, hotels, meals, and other travel expenses it can get very expensive.The
math is simple. If we raise no money, we will do what we can locally with what
we have. If we raise a thousand dollars, maybe we can do a little more. If we
raise $20K, we can make something decent and worth watching. If we raise $100K,
we can make a quality movie that will do this cause justice and reach a much,
much larger audience and hopefully help that many more people with their daily
struggle!
The Title:
Many
have asked about the name “The Stain of War”, as it can sound anti-war, or
anti-troop upon initially hearing it. I assure you it is not us saying that
troops are “stained” after combat. When I returned from war, I heard many times
people talk about the stigma that comes with combat PTSD. I heard many talk
about how they couldn’t discuss what they saw and did with their loved ones,
because they did not want to be looked at differently. I’ve heard Combat
Veterans discuss how they felt they have a “stain on their soul” after seeing
what they saw, or doing what they had to do.
One
day, I came across a poem by a gentleman named Lonn Sweeney, called “Who Loves
the Warrior”. After years of seeing people point their fingers at the VA and
everyone else for not doing enough and reading the poem, I decided that it was
us, as fellow Veterans, fellow Warriors, who had to stand up and help to “remove
this stain”. That is where the name comes from and our mission is simply to
remove the Stain of War! Below is Lonn’s Poem.
Who loves the Warrior?
Not those he has fought for, for those he has fought for have seen the stain of
battle on his garment.
They draw back when they learn of the deed he has done to keep them safe.
It is better for them to keep a distance from the warrior so the stain will not
spoil the perception of their dignity.
Yet the warrior continues to give his all.
He must fight the battles to keep those
souls he loves free from harm and free from the stain of evil, for he is a
warrior, the only shield between good and evil, it is only the warrior who
loves the warrior.",7.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Philadelphia, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-stain-of-war/pica

The Story:

Zombie Tsunami begins on a secret military island that the general public knows nothing about
column2:
this is where experiments are being conducted to create super soldiers of the undead, which the U.S. government plans to deploy to North Korea in an effort to overthrow Kim Jong-un and free the oppressed citizens. But when an earthquake hits the island, a massive tsunami follows, dragging the undead out to sea and washing them up on Santa Monica beach. Shockwaves from the island earthquake start creating a ripple effect which causes more devastating tsunami action in L.A., thus washing ashore more hoards of the undead. The first to go are the surfers who were stoked on the big surf. Next, the drunk bums on the beach because they assume the zombies are their own kind due to their atrocious odor and uneasy gait. Subsequently, the tourists are picked off. A team of street smart vendors and artists join forces with the LAPD in order to stop the zombies from getting to Hollywood where they will undoubtedly feast on the brains of the rich and famous and destroy the entertainment industry indefinitely. 

The Team:

column1:
Sagan Amery (writer/producer) is a creative juggernaut. Zombie Tsunami is an idea she had while pondering the sheer insanity of Sharknado's success. She loves sharks but what's more realistic: sharks in a tornado or the Zombie Tsunami plot? When she's not writing, creating art and corrupting society, she's performing with her metal band and making kick ass music. Sagan has tons of film ideas, and is currently working on the sequel to Zombie Tsunami which will be titled Zombicane: set in NYC, a hurricane bigger than Sandy washes up on Battery Park, but there's a ghoulish surprise in the surging waters... 

Tzang Merwyn Tong (director/story consultant) is an award-winning underground filmmaker and screenwriter from Singapore, noted for the films [e'Tzaintes] (2003), A Wicked Tale (2005), V1k1 - A Techno Fairytale (2010). Tzang's films are characterised by his off-beat style, often set in a surreal environment, incorporating elements of fairytale and comic fantasy.[1]Tzang founded his own production company INRI studio in 1999.[2] He is the youngest Singaporean to ever release a film commercially on DVD/VCD.[3] His latest film Faeryville, a dystopian teen movie, is due for international release in 2015. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tzang_Merwyn_Tong

""Moichandising! Moichandising! Where the real money from the movie is made. Zombie Tsunami: the T-shirt, Zombie Tsunami: the Coloring Book, Zombie Tsunami: the Lunchbox, Zombie Tsunami: the Breakfast Cereal! Zombie Tsunami: the Flame Thrower!""

The Budget:

Why $1,000,000? ""Don't you think we should ask for *more* than a million dollars? A million dollars isn't exactly a lot of money these days. Virtucon alone makes over 9 billion dollars a year!"" Because Sharknado was made for $2,000,000 and we think we can do a better job for a smaller budget. And if we don't hit our goal, we're still going to make this film, albeit a cheesier version due to funding issues. BUT YOU NEED THIS FILM!! YOU NEED A TSUNAMI TO WASH ZOMBIES ASHORE L.A. AND THREATEN THE LIVELIHOOD OF PEOPLE LIKE THE KARDASHIANS (hint).

Updates:

We will keep you apprised of all aspects of the process of making this film and we will include you in this film whenever possible. You want your kid in the movie? Great, just help us get funded, because nepotism and money makes films. Whatever you can donate will help tremendously and don't forget to share this on your social media pages.

Who We Are

We are a collective group of filmmakers with backgrounds in independent feature films, commercial work, and short film work. Our cast and crew include working professionals and students currently in film school. Our resources include decades of experience, professional gear (RED Cameras, ARRI Lighting, DaVinci Resolve Suite, THX Mixing Theatre), and a passion for filmmaking.
The Story

If you've seen the teaser trailer or the video above, you have a general idea what this story is about. We're creating a narrative that will raise questions about violence in our media and how we as a society respond to it.
<div>Our story starts with a man named Ben Reed, who after a long day at work is on his way to his car. He comes across an argument which turns into a fight. Ben has a decision to make
column2: does he step in and do something or does he continue on his way? As Ben makes his decision, the scenario is recorded on a phone and then uploaded for the world to see. Ben's life changes overnight as society and media pull apart the details of the video, only to discover that there was more to the scenario than Ben understood.

column1: We want you to join us as we create a film that makes a statement about violence in our media.

Where Your Contributions Will Go

If you decide to contribute to the campaign, your contributions will go towards:

  • Gear Rentals (Specifically: Lenses)
• Truck Rental to transport gear to and from set.
• Food for Cast and Crew.
• Props
• Set Dressing
• Back into the Indiegogo perks
We want you to feel like you're apart of the project, so we've carefully selected perks that will get you in on the action! Some perks include:
• A Digital Script
• Production Stills
• Props
• Digital HD Download of Film
• BluRay copy of Film
• Exclusive Poster
• Hand Written Letters
• Physical Script
• Film Credits
Rest assure, if we don't reach our goal, every penny of your contribution will still go to the production of this film.

The Impact

A film that will raise questions... questions we believe people need to ask.

  • This film will get people talking about current social issues in a way that media doesn't usually address them. 
  • We want to create something that will cause people to think for themselves through entertaining narrative.

Challenges

As filmmakers, we try to be incredibly careful about the art we create.

The subject material of this film can be very touchy (subjects that people generally try to avoid). One of the biggest challenges with this film is how to delicately handle the issue of violence in media, something that has affected a variety of people.
We have and will continue to carefully craft the film in a way that isn't ""preachy""  while handling the material in a sensitive way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but would still like to get involved, here are some ways you can help.

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Like our Facebook or Twitter pages!
• Share our Teaser Trailer.

• Use the Indiegogo Share links to show more people the campaign.

    • Thank You once again for your contributions and all you help!


    Common Questions

    Is this a documentary or a true story?
• A Shared Silence is a thrilling fictional narrative.
What will happen to my money if you don't reach your goal?

• Every contribution will go directly toward the production of the film whether we reach our goal or not. You will receive your perk even if we don't reach our goal.
Will this film include actual news footage?

  • A Shared Silence will only include footage shot by our production team. Our teaser trailer was created to provide actual examples of violence in media.

column7:
>With a desire for adventure, Lee Maxwell has never ceased to amaze people with his creativity and urge to explore the world. After being told that exploring is to dangerous, Lee takes it upon himself to do what he loves even if the consequences are deathly.

About Us:

column1: Jay Batchler (Writer/Producer/Director of Photography/Editor):

Jay is a Sophomore at UNCSA interested in the world of camera, lighting, and editing. Jay has had experience on sets of commercials, short films, and music videos. In his off time, Jay is a avid photographer and loves to capture people and nature in their natural environment.

Caleb Ennis (Co-Writer/Director):

column2:
>

Caleb Ennis is a fourth year film directing major in the filmmaking program at UNCSA. He is from Winston-Salem, North Carolina. Caleb has been an extras casting coordinator for an independent feature film and directed a 10-minute short film with a budget of $1,500. In the summer of 2015, he directed a stage play called ""Mississippi Born and Bred"" starring Tonea Stewart (A Time to Kill ) at the National Black Theatre festival.

column1: Dustin Chandler (Co-Writer/Story):

column3:
/>

""Dustin Chandler is a fourth year screenwriting major at UNCSA. Originally from Connelly Springs, NC, he is the writer/director of the documentary BEYOND THE BLUE and has worked as an assistant director on a number of short films, music videos and features. He is also a contributing film critic for the UK based website Watch This Space Film Magazine.""

need your support in order to provide legal and legislative assistance to the
Fort Peck Assiniboine and Sioux Nations as they combat the exploitation of their

Tribal youth. 
On Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana, Native children--some as young as nine--are being used for sex trafficking in the “man camps” of transient worker populations lured to the region because of lucrative jobs in fracking.
<h3><b>THE
ISSUE
Native
children on Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana are being exploited through sex trafficking in record
numbers.  While many people understand
sex trafficking to be a largely international issue, involving kidnapping and urban
sex rings with foreign national workers, many Native minors are currently being
prostituted by adults nationwide, and the problem has grown particularly bad
for Fort Peck.  In an area of North
Dakota a few miles to the East of Fort Peck, known as “the Bakken,” a
catastrophic Wild West has emerged.  Young men are swarming
the region in astonishing numbers because of the promise of lucrative jobs in fracking. Fort Peck has seen an
unprecedented surge of violent crime and sex and drug trafficking, overwhelming the already extremely limited law enforcement resources in the area.
Fort
Peck’s Native children—some as young as nine--are being used in the “man camps”
of transient Bakken worker populations.
Young people are recruited from powwows and local convenience stores.  Child brothels operate out of trailers on the
Reservation.  The tribes do not have a
law enforcement, prosecutorial, or victim services framework to handle this
sharply escalating problem.  Notably,
they also lack a tribal code provision that criminalizes child trafficking and therefore
lack ability to call attention to the problem, educate law enforcement, and

identify victims.

BACKGROUND ON FORT PECK

600 miles east of the well-traveled majesty of Glacier National Park, the mountains give way to a generous spread of badlands and plains, and empty into a place that, it seems, time has forgotten. The Fort Peck Reservation is home of Montana’s oldest rodeo and the Assiniboine and Sioux Indian Nations. 

Fort Peck is as remote as any inhabited region of the United States.  The landscape stretches out endlessly under the bright glare of open and unrelenting skies, with small dusty homesteads and trailers dotting the landscape.  While beautiful, especially amid the sacred badlands at sunset, or along the wild and unpopulated Missouri River Breaks, this is a very difficult place in which to exist.  The Fort Peck Tribal community endures crippling poverty
column2: 50% of children live below the poverty line, and access to all human services is acutely limited.  Young people on the Reservation experience all of the accepted ""vulnerability factors"" for trafficking, including a high rate of child welfare system involvement and extraordinary rates of substance abuse, mental illness, and PTSD.

column1:
THE IMPACT 

Your support can help us provide legal and legislative assistance to the youth, community organizations, and Tribal Government working to fight trafficking.

We will travel to Fort Peck to interview victims, advocates, and community members, and work with them to develop solutions. We hope that our work will enable local institutions to better protect vulnerable youth and respond to their exploitation. In particular, we will:
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Collect evidence about the problem, including primary routes into trafficking for local youth, how trafficking is currently being addressed, and organizations and systems best positioned to identify and protect vulnerable youth

column1: <li><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Draft culturally appropriate anti-trafficking legislation with the Tribal Legislature, allowing them to prosecute offenders and to identify victims.  The Tribal Executive Board recently passed a Tribal Resolution authorizing Melina and her students to do this

column1: <li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Engage Tribal Elders and victim service providers regarding solutions, including their ideas for healing youth using traditional cultural methods

column1: <li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Reverse the punitive and shaming ways youth are often treated by law enforcement and develop a best practices victim response protocol

column1: <li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Call attention to the issue and solutions through articles, reports, and other medial tools.

column1: ABOUT US
Melina
Healey is the Policy Fellow for the Loyola University Chicago School of Law Child
Law Policy and Legislation Clinic. She has worked closely for four years on child
law and civil rights and conducted extensive research, scholarship and advocacy
with the Assiniboine and Sioux Nations on Fort Peck Indian Reservation. She is working
with the Fort Peck Family Violence Resource Center, the Fort Peck Tribal
Executive Board, Loyola clinic students, and the Center for the Human Rights of
Children to draft child trafficking legislation for the Fort Peck Tribal Code, develop
culturally-sensitive guidelines for identifying, treating, and protecting
victims, and to produce a report with findings and recommendations.
Rebecca
Gerome just graduated law school and is volunteering with the project. She has
several years of experience researching the links between gun violence and
gender and interviewing survivors, lawyers, local
authorities, prosecutors, health professionals and social workers around the world. She has published several articles and reports used by
governments and international organizations. At NYU Law, she volunteered
with the Anti-Trafficking Advocacy Coalition (ATAC) and participated in a legal
clinic for trafficked youth.
If you would like to make tax deductible donation (if you do this please let us know by email at melina.healey@gmail.com otherwise we will not receive the funds for this project)
1. Navigate to http://www.luc.edu/chrc/
2. Click the ""support the center"" tab
3. For ""choose an area to support"" click ""other"" and
4. Write in the ""if you selected other, please describe here"" box ""Center for the Human Rights of Children--Fort Peck Child Trafficking Project""
5. Let us know so we can be sure the funds go to this project!
","We
need your support in order to provide legal and legislative assistance to the
Fort Peck Assiniboine and Sioux Nations as they combat the exploitation of their

Tribal youth. On Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana, Native children--some as young as nine--are being used for sex trafficking in the “man camps” of transient worker populations lured to the region because of lucrative jobs in fracking.
THE
ISSUE
Native
children on Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana are being exploited through sex trafficking in record
numbers.  While many people understand
sex trafficking to be a largely international issue, involving kidnapping and urban
sex rings with foreign national workers, many Native minors are currently being
prostituted by adults nationwide, and the problem has grown particularly bad
for Fort Peck.  In an area of North
Dakota a few miles to the East of Fort Peck, known as “the Bakken,” a
catastrophic Wild West has emerged.  Young men are swarming
the region in astonishing numbers because of the promise of lucrative jobs in fracking. Fort Peck has seen an
unprecedented surge of violent crime and sex and drug trafficking, overwhelming the already extremely limited law enforcement resources in the area.
Fort
Peck’s Native children—some as young as nine--are being used in the “man camps”
of transient Bakken worker populations.
Young people are recruited from powwows and local convenience stores.  Child brothels operate out of trailers on the
Reservation.  The tribes do not have a
law enforcement, prosecutorial, or victim services framework to handle this
sharply escalating problem.  Notably,
they also lack a tribal code provision that criminalizes child trafficking and therefore
lack ability to call attention to the problem, educate law enforcement, and

identify victims.BACKGROUND ON FORT PECK600 miles east of the well-traveled majesty of Glacier National Park, the mountains give way to a generous spread of badlands and plains, and empty into a place that, it seems, time has forgotten. The Fort Peck Reservation is home of Montana’s oldest rodeo and the Assiniboine and Sioux Indian Nations. Fort Peck is as remote as any inhabited region of the United States.  The landscape stretches out endlessly under the bright glare of open and unrelenting skies, with small dusty homesteads and trailers dotting the landscape.  While beautiful, especially amid the sacred badlands at sunset, or along the wild and unpopulated Missouri River Breaks, this is a very difficult place in which to exist.  The Fort Peck Tribal community endures crippling poverty
column2: 50% of children live below the poverty line, and access to all human services is acutely limited.  Young people on the Reservation experience all of the accepted ""vulnerability factors"" for trafficking, including a high rate of child welfare system involvement and extraordinary rates of substance abuse, mental illness, and PTSD.

column1: THE IMPACT Your support can help us provide legal and legislative assistance to the youth, community organizations, and Tribal Government working to fight trafficking.We will travel to Fort Peck to interview victims, advocates, and community members, and work with them to develop solutions. We hope that our work will enable local institutions to better protect vulnerable youth and respond to their exploitation. In particular, we will:

Collect evidence about the problem, including primary routes into trafficking for local youth, how trafficking is currently being addressed, and organizations and systems best positioned to identify and protect vulnerable youth

Draft culturally appropriate anti-trafficking legislation with the Tribal Legislature, allowing them to prosecute offenders and to identify victims.  The Tribal Executive Board recently passed a Tribal Resolution authorizing Melina and her students to do this
Engage Tribal Elders and victim service providers regarding solutions, including their ideas for healing youth using traditional cultural methods
Reverse the punitive and shaming ways youth are often treated by law enforcement and develop a best practices victim response protocol
Call attention to the issue and solutions through articles, reports, and other medial tools.
ABOUT US
Melina
Healey is the Policy Fellow for the Loyola University Chicago School of Law Child
Law Policy and Legislation Clinic. She has worked closely for four years on child
law and civil rights and conducted extensive research, scholarship and advocacy
with the Assiniboine and Sioux Nations on Fort Peck Indian Reservation. She is working
with the Fort Peck Family Violence Resource Center, the Fort Peck Tribal
Executive Board, Loyola clinic students, and the Center for the Human Rights of
Children to draft child trafficking legislation for the Fort Peck Tribal Code, develop
culturally-sensitive guidelines for identifying, treating, and protecting
victims, and to produce a report with findings and recommendations.
Rebecca
Gerome just graduated law school and is volunteering with the project. She has
several years of experience researching the links between gun violence and
gender and interviewing survivors, lawyers, local
authorities, prosecutors, health professionals and social workers around the world. She has published several articles and reports used by
governments and international organizations. At NYU Law, she volunteered
with the Anti-Trafficking Advocacy Coalition (ATAC) and participated in a legal
clinic for trafficked youth.
If you would like to make tax deductible donation (if you do this please let us know by email at melina.healey@gmail.com otherwise we will not receive the funds for this project)

The story!
A year ago, I left Belgium, and my family to jump on a plane direction LA. I had never hold a camera in my hands but decided to invest all my savings in film making studies. Is that crazy?
Wait a minute, if I’m crazy, why
should you contribute to our campaign?
Because a hint of craziness is what

keep us sane!

Image author: Harry Spitz

This short movie is an homage to what

I’ve lived in LA, to positive craziness and an encouragement to those who still have to get crazy to really be themselves.

It's a psychological
drama in the vain of American Beauty but through the vision of a woman
protagonist. It will bring us into the life of Judith and Walter, a middle
class couple who once had big dreams which shattered along the way and took
the form of heavy luggage made out of anger, resentment and depression. They
now both carry those feelings in their daily life as their own

shadows, pulling them backward.

What happens in the movie?

We'll follow Judith and Walter through the course of a day, but not any day. It's Walter's big day at his company, a huge client is coming to sign a game changer contract. Judith will host a party during the evening to celebrate the contract, inviting 20 people. The stress of the day combined with the party preparations will quickly bring Judith very close to a mental breakdown. A twist of events will show us at the end that her collapse might still come from something very different...
Psychological because it brings a
message.
The audience will embark in a
journey through a love/hate relationship with the characters in parallelism of
the love/hate relationship the characters are themselves living. Symbolism,
visual and audio clues will be used throughout the movie to bring a unique
experience to the audience. We want the audience to understand and feel how

life choices can bring you happiness or as Judith and Walter live, sadness and misery.

Where are we at now?
Currently, this journey has  the form
of a 15 pages script, 20 person crew, ideas and dreams. <b>By contributing you’ll help us make
our dream a reality! This campaign will help us gather the funds
for the pre-production and production of the short film.
<h2 align=""center""><b>Who
are we?
Alexi VDS,
Writer, Producer, Director.
column3:
/>

Alexi is a Belgian writer and director

column1: born on March 18, 1981 in Belgium. Before starting his new life in LA as a
movie director, Alexi studied IT and Kinesiology. Those two activities gave him tremendous
assets for his new career. The mix of project management skills and psychology
knowledge help him in all the steps of movie creation, on set and off set. What
is most dear to him is to share visions and messages that his audience

benefit from by watching his movies.

John Rosario, Director of photography.
column3:
/>

John is known for his work on Zugzwang (2015), Coming to Terms (2015) and Beneath the Sheets (2008).

Jessica Nave Di Serio, Co-Producer.

column1: is from Brazil. She has a bachelors degree on producing for television
and radio and is now studying to be a filmmaker in Los Angeles. She also
has experience on the entertainment business having worked at Disney
World two times as a performer. She believes in the art of film making as the best way of bringing stories and important messages to people

around the world.

Paula Neves, Production Designer.
column3:
/>

Paula is from Brazil. She studied Social Communication in Audiovisual media (TV, Cinema and Radio) in college. She's now a Filmmaker Student at the New York Film Academy. She worked as a writer for two years in a company and later on as CFO. During her college years in Brazil, she participated in over 15 short films. Working as a production designer in 7 of those. She truly believes that films have the power to change peoples life.

Kika Rodriguez, Make-up &
column4: Special FX Artist.
column6:
/>

Kika is an Uruguayan Special Effects makeup artist graduated from the Tom Savini School and director, brought to this country pursuing her love for moviemaking.
