0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3 style=""text-align: left
<span style=""font-size: 16px
column8:
>Howdy. My Name is Muck Sticky.

Since 1999, I’ve been making music, music

column1: videos, and short films. With 18 albums, more than 50 music videos, several
short films, and over 25 million downloads of my content, it seems that many of you
enjoy what I create. And I certainly enjoy being creative.  But I am constantly asked: “When are you
gonna make a movie?
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Well, here is your chance to help me make a musical-comedic-adventure movie based on my life experiences! And maybe even be IN the movie too...
column3: >IF WE CAN RAISE $50k by Feb 24th, the movie will be made THIS YEAR and released in early 2017

column1: Synopsis: 'Dig That!' is a movie based on the life of Muck Sticky, a struggling artist on a mission to share his message with the world. After his neighbors, friends, strangers, and even family members discourage him by suggesting he will never find success as a pajama-wearing musician, he perseveres through years of triumphs and tragedies to pursue his dreams and live the life he loves. This epic comedy-adventure through the mind of Mervous Thrifty will leave you laughing, crying, celebrating, and sitting on the edge of your seat.
A little bit of history
In 2012, with the help of some friends, we made a 60-minute suspense film
called “Muscadine Wine” for less than $1,000, thanks to the amazing help of our friends. We had 2 FULL CAPACITY premiere screenings in Memphis,
TN, (where the movie was filmed), and we did a LIMITED EDITION DVD release that SOLD OUT. Again, it was done with NO BUDGET. But we finished it! And
judging by the reviews from those who’ve seen it, people seem to dig it. Here
is the trailer…

In 2006, I wrote my adventurous dramatic-comedy script called “Dig That!”, and we attempted to film it with NO BUDGET. Which was a BIG mistake. A few scenes into filming, with sub-par equipment, the camera broke and we had to put everything on hold…until now! With your help, we can finally make this movie and get it released.
Starting NOW, I need your help to fund the production, and

possibly even be involved in the movie itself. Here is how your help will help, and how you can even be part of the movie...YES, I said be part of it...as in, have a part in the movie:

  • By contributing NOW, you can help ensure that we get the production started. Once we get underway, there will be new opportunities to get involved and be part of the crew/cast.
<li>The BIGGER the BUDGET =The more cool stuff we can do! (crazier stunts, niftier locations, cameos from well-known actors, musicians, &amp
column2:
celebrities, etc.)
  • Get LIMITED EDITION perks including DVDs, CDs, and T-shirts. These will ONLY be available during this campaign. Once we collect the orders and have them printed, there will be NO MORE. So reserve yours NOW!

column1: • If we don't reach the goal, we will still make a cool short film and send the perks to everyone who orders. But I know you freaky fun-loving weirdos want to see this movie get made, so let's do this!
<li>
In order to get good distribution, and possibly get it into
theatres, we need to prove that there are enough of you demanding to see it. We
need to show the distributors that people besides my friends and family will
show up to see it, or maybe even watch it on Netflix.
<div>
<div>
Here are some of the reasons we need a budget to get started:
<ol>
• Hire a cinematographer so I don’t have to set up the camera myself, and then act in front of it (it makes it very difficult to get moving shots).
• Get better equipment + transportation of said equipment.

• Pay an awesome crew to work on set taking care of all the crazy stuff that needs to be taken care of so we can make a really freaking awesome movie!
    A GOOD CREW IS ESSENTIAL TO MAKING A GOOD FILM.
• Manufacture the products you will be ordering (DVDs, T-shirts, CDs, etc.) So please be sure and ADD an extra contribution when completing your perk.
<li>Pay our personal photographer to stay on set and take pictures so we can give you special behind-the-scenes footage &amp
column2: photos. Once you order ANY PERK, you are automatically subscribed to get updates from the set of the movie.

column1: I’ve been waiting 10 years to make my movie ""Dig That!"". This movie is very special to me. To do it the way I’ve always dreamed of doing it, we need a BIG BUDGET. So our main goal is $1,000,000. And we need to raise it OURSELVES! Which isn't crazy considering most movies have multi-million dollar budgets. But to simply get started and ensure we get to work on the movie this year (2016), we need to raise at least $50k by February 24th. Once we hit $50k and go 'in-demand', there is NO LIMIT to how much we can raise. So please CONTRIBUTE NOW, and contribute often. As we progress, we will release new 'stretch goals' and unlock new perks, as well as release new info and updates about the movie (movie stars, production secrets, etc.). The bigger the budget we raise together, the better the movie we can make! That's just how movie-making works. Here are some of the perks we have...

This once in a lifetime mov...no wait. This movie will never be on Lifetime. Let me rephrase. column1: <h3>Risks &amp

Of course, there are always great risks and challenges when making a movie. That kinda goes without saying, but too late because I already said it. And everyone knows that in order to achieve great things, you must take great risks. And that's what this movie is actually all about. Taking risks. It tells the story of a guy who struggles between being stuck in a rut and taking a leap of courage. It's an adventurous dramatic comedy with a mission and a purpose. And my mission and purpose are to make this movie in 2016. Are you willing to take the risk with me?

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can contribute aside from ordering perks:
<ol>
<li>

Flood The Internetweb: Whether on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Emails, Blogs, or any other means of spreading the word about this movie campaign electronically, please let EVERYONE know how excited you are to be part of Muck Sticky's movie ""Dig That!"". Share, like, and comment on our posts at Facebook.com/MuckSticky and Facebook.com/DigThatMovie
<li>

Speak Words To Your Friends: We need to reach as many Muck Sticky fans as we possibly can. Over the past 17 years, we've reached a lot of people with the music. Now we need your help to reconnect everyone for this movie.
<li>
Play The Music: No matter how you listen to music, listen to more Muck Sticky. Especially during this campaign. You can also order autographed CDs at MuckSticky.com/store
<li>
<b>Grab Extra Perks For Friends &amp
column2: Family: Imagine how much your peeps will appreciate you getting them LIMITED EDITION stuff from this movie.

column1:
And that's all there is to it. So choose a perk, add a contribution, and let's make a movie!

","Howdy. My Name is Muck Sticky.Since 1999, I’ve been making music, music
videos, and short films. With 18 albums, more than 50 music videos, several
short films, and over 25 million downloads of my content, it seems that many of you
enjoy what I create. And I certainly enjoy being creative.  But I am constantly asked: “When are you
gonna make a movie?

Well, here is your chance to help me make a musical-comedic-adventure movie based on my life experiences! And maybe even be IN the movie too...IF WE CAN RAISE $50k by Feb 24th, the movie will be made THIS YEAR and released in early 2017

Synopsis: 'Dig That!' is a movie based on the life of Muck Sticky, a struggling artist on a mission to share his message with the world. After his neighbors, friends, strangers, and even family members discourage him by suggesting he will never find success as a pajama-wearing musician, he perseveres through years of triumphs and tragedies to pursue his dreams and live the life he loves. This epic comedy-adventure through the mind of Mervous Thrifty will leave you laughing, crying, celebrating, and sitting on the edge of your seat.
A little bit of history
In 2012, with the help of some friends, we made a 60-minute suspense film
called “Muscadine Wine” for less than $1,000, thanks to the amazing help of our friends. We had 2 FULL CAPACITY premiere screenings in Memphis,
TN, (where the movie was filmed), and we did a LIMITED EDITION DVD release that SOLD OUT. Again, it was done with NO BUDGET. But we finished it! And
judging by the reviews from those who’ve seen it, people seem to dig it. Here
is the trailer…
1st Goal: $50,000 by February 24th, 2016

In 2006, I wrote my adventurous dramatic-comedy script called “Dig That!”, and we attempted to film it with NO BUDGET. Which was a BIG mistake. A few scenes into filming, with sub-par equipment, the camera broke and we had to put everything on hold…until now! With your help, we can finally make this movie and get it released.
Starting NOW, I need your help to fund the production, and

possibly even be involved in the movie itself. Here is how your help will help, and how you can even be part of the movie...YES, I said be part of it...as in, have a part in the movie:  By contributing NOW, you can help ensure that we get the production started. Once we get underway, there will be new opportunities to get involved and be part of the crew/cast.

The BIGGER the BUDGET =The more cool stuff we can do! (crazier stunts, niftier locations, cameos from well-known actors, musicians, & celebrities, etc.) Get LIMITED EDITION perks including DVDs, CDs, and T-shirts. These will ONLY be available during this campaign. Once we collect the orders and have them printed, there will be NO MORE. So reserve yours NOW!
If we don't reach the goal, we will still make a cool short film and send the perks to everyone who orders. But I know you freaky fun-loving weirdos want to see this movie get made, so let's do this!
In order to get good distribution, and possibly get it into
theatres, we need to prove that there are enough of you demanding to see it. We
need to show the distributors that people besides my friends and family will
show up to see it, or maybe even watch it on Netflix.
Here are some of the reasons we need a budget to get started:
Hire a cinematographer so I don’t have to set up the camera myself, and then act in front of it (it makes it very difficult to get moving shots).
Get better equipment + transportation of said equipment.
Pay an awesome crew to work on set taking care of all the crazy stuff that needs to be taken care of so we can make a really freaking awesome movie!A GOOD CREW IS ESSENTIAL TO MAKING A GOOD FILM.
Manufacture the products you will be ordering (DVDs, T-shirts, CDs, etc.) So please be sure and ADD an extra contribution when completing your perk.

Pay our personal photographer to stay on set and take pictures so we can give you special behind-the-scenes footage & photos. Once you order ANY PERK, you are automatically subscribed to get updates from the set of the movie.

I’ve been waiting 10 years to make my movie ""Dig That!"". This movie is very special to me. To do it the way I’ve always dreamed of doing it, we need a BIG BUDGET. So our main goal is $1,000,000. And we need to raise it OURSELVES! Which isn't crazy considering most movies have multi-million dollar budgets. But to simply get started and ensure we get to work on the movie this year (2016), we need to raise at least $50k by February 24th. Once we hit $50k and go 'in-demand', there is NO LIMIT to how much we can raise. So please CONTRIBUTE NOW, and contribute often. As we progress, we will release new 'stretch goals' and unlock new perks, as well as release new info and updates about the movie (movie stars, production secrets, etc.). The bigger the budget we raise together, the better the movie we can make! That's just how movie-making works. Here are some of the perks we have...
Extra Perks:
$100 - ""Name in the credits""Anyone who contributes more than $100 (in contributions, not perks), will get to see their name listed in the 'thank you' credits at the end of the movie.
$500 - ""I wanna be in your movie""

Wanna be seen in a scene? You could be 'Guy Walking Down Street'. Or you could even be 'Girl Sitting In Restaurant'. Anyone who supports this movie enough to chip in over $500 (in contributions, not perks), will be guaranteed to be an extra in a scene in the movie. (must provide your own travel/expenses to Memphis, TN)

$1,000 - ""I'm ready for my close-up, mister Sticky""Ever wanted to be that person who they cut to for a reaction shot when something happens in a movie? Well, here's your chance! Those of you who contribute more than $1,000 smackaroos (in contributions, not perks), will get a close up shot somewhere in the flick. (Again, must provide your own travel/expenses to Memphis, TN)

$2,000 - ""Just give me, like, one line or something""If you are an up and coming actor and you want a really cool credit on your resume, or you just want to say something in a movie so you can brag to your friends, here is your chance to have a speaking role in ""Dig That!"". This once in a lifetime mov...no wait. This movie will never be on Lifetime. Let me rephrase. This once in a lifetime opportunity is only available to 5 people who contribute more than $2,000 (in contributions, not perks).

$5,000 - Executive ProducerIf you've ever wanted to see your name in the credits of a movie as an Executive Producer, this is your chance (in contributions, not perks). Because Executive Producers do just that. They enable the execution of the production. Which means they put in money to help it get made. Or if you've already been one, and want to be one again, this will be a great addition to your titles.

$15,000 - Keep The VanWe need to recreate the wrapped Muck Sticky van that was used between 2006-2012 for touring & promotion. If you contribute $15,000 (in contributions, not perks) to help us recreate this for the movie, you will get to keep the van after the movie is finished filming. (note: Only one available, and you will be responsible for picking up the van from the set in Memphis.)
The Impact
Your contribution to the making of this movie will certainly bring great joy to many people when they watch it:

Not only will you enjoy watching the process of this movie being made with your inside access, but you will also be making a difference in my life personally. This project has been sitting unfinished for ten years. Bringing it back to life and completing it will fulfill part of my soul.

As many of you know, I have spent the last 15 years creating albums, videos, and short films with a bare-minimum budget. Think of what I can do with a REAL budget!! I can only dream about the kind of movie I want to make for now. But if you help me raise enough money, my dreams can become a reality! At least on-screen...

We had over 1,000 people contribute to Muck Sticky album campaigns in 2015, raising over $30,000. And we delivered everything we promised! That is why I feel CERTAIN that you will step-up and help me bring this movie to life.
Risks & Challenges

Of course, there are always great risks and challenges when making a movie. That kinda goes without saying, but too late because I already said it. And everyone knows that in order to achieve great things, you must take great risks. And that's what this movie is actually all about. Taking risks. It tells the story of a guy who struggles between being stuck in a rut and taking a leap of courage. It's an adventurous dramatic comedy with a mission and a purpose. And my mission and purpose are to make this movie in 2016. Are you willing to take the risk with me?   Other Ways You Can Help There are other ways you can contribute aside from ordering perks:

Flood The Internetweb: Whether on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Emails, Blogs, or any other means of spreading the word about this movie campaign electronically, please let EVERYONE know how excited you are to be part of Muck Sticky's movie ""Dig That!"". Share, like, and comment on our posts at Facebook.com/MuckSticky and Facebook.com/DigThatMovie

Speak Words To Your Friends: We need to reach as many Muck Sticky fans as we possibly can. Over the past 17 years, we've reached a lot of people with the music. Now we need your help to reconnect everyone for this movie.
Play The Music: No matter how you listen to music, listen to more Muck Sticky. Especially during this campaign. You can also order autographed CDs at MuckSticky.com/store
Grab Extra Perks For Friends & Family: Imagine how much your peeps will appreciate you getting them LIMITED EDITION stuff from this movie.
And that's all there is to it. So choose a perk, add a contribution, and let's make a movie!",11.0,1,"10 Campaigns

Short Summary

My name is James Avelar. I am the producer, writer and director of SHINE BRIGHT.
I have a Bachelor's Degree from California State University at Los Angeles in Broadcasting with an option in Film &
column2:
Television. Film has always been an important part of my life. Ever since I was a kid and saw E.T., it had an emotional impact on me. With this, I knew film can make you cry, laugh and become part of the film's world. This is what I want to do with an audience, I want to take them on an emotional journey. I want an audience to escape.

SHINE BRIGHT is a film I want to tell. It is a story about family, about tragedy, about love, about conflicts. We all go through hardships in life. We deal with consequences. But in the end, we can rely on family. It is all that we have. In this story the two sisters, Andie and Genesis are the only family they have. They need each other.

This campaign will make my story come to life. The contributions will help us achieve in telling this story.
Making a film is not easy. It takes an army. From pre-production to production to post-production, assembling a crew is an essential necessity. And with your contributions we can succeed in hiring the best people for the job.

 In order to make this film I will need $25,000. The money will be divided into 4 different categories:
20%- Pre-production
40%- Production
30%- Post Production
10%- Promotion

As you can see, your contributions will come with some perks. We have broken down the different amounts into categories.

Even if we don't meet our goal, we will use what we have achieved and use the amount as resourceful as possible. Again, with an army of collaborators anything can be achieved.

***But you can donate as little as a $1.00 if you want. Anything helps!***


    We have assembled some great actors for the film. With their talents, the film will succeed in telling the story. They are committed and excited about the film.

column1: I have included a  trailer we shot for the film and a short film, titled HOME, I shot last year as an example of my previous work.

Even if you cannot contribute, it will mean so much to simply spread the word. We have a twitter and facebook. The more our film is out there, the more contributions we can receive.

Thank you so much!!

TO INHALE THE MOVIE
Become a supporting member in the

production community of the next best movie sensation, starring Shawty Shawty the comedian, who's best known for Nick Cannon's MTV's ‘Wild n Out’.

We are

now in the casting stage of the production.  Our casting call is scheduled for May 14, 2016. The overall budget for the production of this film is roughly $80,000.  We have raised more than $35,000 and now we need to raise the remaining $45,000
for things such as, hiring additional actors and a marketing team for post production,
column4: >continuing to pay our professional film production crew, pay compensations, legal fees, and a number of other

column1:
production expenses needed to produce a successful film.

Imagine a comedy where people are breaking the law while at the same time supporting a push for a new law.
In this independent comedy, a common
real-life story is told in a funny way that actually makes a serious case for
marijuana to be fully legalized – not only for medical purposes, but for
recreational usage as well.
In “Waiting to Inhale The Movie”, a group of
young men spend an entire day in Atlanta in search of recreational marijuana.  Throughout this hilarious journey, they run into crazy obstacles along the way.
From unscrupulous dealers selling
them fake marijuana, to the police trying to catch them red handed, our movie’s
heroes go through a funny and dangerous adventure to get their Marijuana –
while anxiously awaiting the decision from the high courts that is expected to legalize
recreational marijuana in the state of Georgia.
column6: schema=youtube"" width=""580"">
column9: >In short, Waiting to Inhale the movie is a family comedy that will take the audience on a gut busting journey, as our Movie hero's try to find the marijuana that will

column1: give them the high that they have been in search of all day. This film will have you take another prospective on the whole issue of the use and legalization of marijuana.

Instagram - @waitintoinhale

That’s why we have secured a major role for you – we want you to become a member of our production team.  How do we make this happen?  You can show your support for our project,
that combines comedy and the highlights the serious issue behind the legalization of recreational marijuana by:
Selecting
one of the many exciting perks that we have carefully prepared for you.
Sharing
this crowdfunding initiative with your friends and family who also like
to have a good laugh – and support the legalization of recreational marijuana.
Thank you, and we hope to be welcoming you to the production team
of “Waiting to Inhale The Movie”.

**Any proceeds of the funding that is not used upon completion of this production, a portion of those proceeds will be donated to National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws -NORML -www.norml.org**

Short Summary

Katherine Dudley (Director) &
students at Full Sail University. Our project THE BET was picked to be
our class thesis film, and we are really excited about putting this
project together and showing it to the world.

This is comedy about two friends who are always in friendly competition with each other. However one isn't so great at winning. Things are different this time when they make a wager where is makes the rules. Things are sure to get heated, and you're going to want to see who comes out on top.
We NEED your help (which translate to your hard earned money) to get the ball rolling on this thing. It would be monumental if you contribute even just a little bit!
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

The break down of what you're assisting with:

-We have the crew, and like any family with a litter of kids they have to be fed.
-We have the locations. We just have to cover the cost to use them.
-We have the equipment. We are lacking in the props department.
-We'll have the film. We want it to be seen.

All funds will be put toward feeding our hard working crew on set. It'll cover location permits and insurance (safety first), and any Film Festivals we enter. As well as props needs to make the project as high quality as possible.

PERKS!!!   Along with helping us get the production value, we have so cool stuff you get in return. Check out our perks below.

The Impact

 As stated before, this is our MFA Thesis project. Which means it is also a major part of us completing our graduate program. However this isn't out first project. Katherine's ""The Perfect Selfie"" documentary is a great example of the quality and effort we put into our work. Chad's experimental film MILK, shows the level of creativity that we have. Our class is very talented and will all input their skills on this film.

column1:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about out campaign.
  • Share the Indiegogo link!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

This film is an action drama, tackling the theme of how bad decisions in the past can have consequences reaching into the future. The main character, Irfan, has just been released from prison under parole, wearing an ankle monitor, to serve out the remainder of his sentence. Back on the outside he tries to make it up to his family, when he is once again approached by Hawar, the man who made it so he ended up in prison in the first place. Desperate to protect his family he commits another crime, ultimately prolonging his prison sentence.

We can all recognize the act of making a choice, perhaps impulsively or in a moment of short-sightedness, and then regretting that choice later in life. Everybody has a past, and your future depends on getting to terms with that past, recognizing and accepting that you can’t change what you have done previously. It is your future actions that define who you are, and who you’ll ultimately end up being.
Who are we?

We are a group of film students, well into our last year of Bachelor studies at the Norwegian film, TV and music school Westerdals Oslo Act. For our last, and definitely largest, production undertaken during these last three years, we want to make an action drama in the vein of Steve McQueen, in which we’ll also to some degree adopt the use of colour and fight choreography and film techniques seen in Asian action films. In other words, we want to make something not seen in Norway previously, and to make this a reality we will need YOUR help!


Director - Ken Pham

Producer - Ane S. Reinholdtsen

Director of photography - Andreas Lie Tøften

Film editor - Heidi Myrvold Andersen

Production sound mixer - Siri Schippers Skaar

Production sound mixer - Simen Normann
Making a film is expensive, we’ve learned that the hard way. We want to make the most out of this opportunity, and with your help we will be able to do the following:

• We want to make a visually challenging and realistic fight scene. To help us achieve this we’ve hired in a very competent stunt team to choreograph and coordinate this scene with us. We will need adequate funds for props and other equipment in order to make the stunts impressive and awe-inspiring enough.

• We already have access to a lot of good camera equipment through our school, but in order to achieve the quality and look we want we’ll need to rent even more. We’ll need to rent some grip equipment, in addition to some sound equipment as well.

The funds provided by you will mainly go towards this. Anything left afterwards will be spent on scenography, makeup and costumes, to give these departments more flexibility. We appreciate any and all support we can get, everything helps!
<div>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
If you do not have the opportunity to help us financially, we completely understand. If so, we would greatly appreciate it if you could share this link, to help us reach as many people as possible.
Thank you so much for all your support, both mentally and physically!
","Synopsis

This film is an action drama, tackling the theme of how bad decisions in the past can have consequences reaching into the future. The main character, Irfan, has just been released from prison under parole, wearing an ankle monitor, to serve out the remainder of his sentence. Back on the outside he tries to make it up to his family, when he is once again approached by Hawar, the man who made it so he ended up in prison in the first place. Desperate to protect his family he commits another crime, ultimately prolonging his prison sentence.

We can all recognize the act of making a choice, perhaps impulsively or in a moment of short-sightedness, and then regretting that choice later in life. Everybody has a past, and your future depends on getting to terms with that past, recognizing and accepting that you can’t change what you have done previously. Determined and adventurous outdoors-man, Zack Starr, vows to defy chronic pain and inspire fellow injured veterans by tackling the “Everest of hiking trails”, the Pacific Crest Trail – 2,650 miles up the West Coast of the United States, despite facing a 5th surgical attempt to repair a service ending shoulder injury.  After 5 months of awe, majesty, weather extremes and athletic success, escalating physical, mental and emotional pain threaten Zack’s finish.  When word reaches him on the trail that the doctor cannot risk offering a final pain relieving shot without destroying what is left of his shoulder, Zack is left near hopeless and in extreme pain.  While originally setting out to prove something to himself and others about pushing through the pain, actually being pushed to the breaking point forces him to reveal and accept a hidden dark part of his past which  nearly resulted in him taking his own life.

In a beautiful irony, Zack’s thoughts focus on his fellow brothers and sisters in the services who face physical and mental blows daily from injury and illness and the 22 veterans a day that will commit suicide.  Holding onto the faith that completing the journey is no longer just a personal challenge, but a necessity for saving lives, he takes it one step at a time and one hour at a time with his eyes on the Canadian terminus.

Short Summary
We live in a world of screens. They're everywhere, pervasive in our lives. We use them for work, play. But it’s much more than
that. The screens use us, too. How did we get here? And where’s this
journey leading us? What does that even look like? And is it what we
want? Is this culture’s technology changing us and our societies for the
better? Does it empower all of us—like it claims to—or does it only
empower a select few at the expense of the many? What’s the price we pay
to live in this pervasive electronic world?
These are the sorts of questions I'm setting out to explore with this documentary film project.
This era is unprecedented, and perhaps never before has technology
been so prolific and shaped our lives so intimately. But there’s a dark
side we don’t talk about and I hope this film project can explore some
of those issues. It will be a polemical film and hard hitting about this
culture's collective addiction to digital technologies and screens.
What is going on here? Technological progress for whom?
This is my first feature length documentary film. I'm an independent
film maker, artist and activist without any budget, funding or backing.
This gives my work authenticity and honesty, but is also a huge ongoing
challenge within our society where money is this culture's power. With
or without your financial help, I'm setting out to make a pertinent film
that informs, inspires and provokes action and radical social and
political change.

What This Project Needs

I need funds to cover expenses to finish conducting interviews,
get them transcribed, as well as to cover some equipment hire and post
production. If I make enough, I also have a plan to
hit the road on tour with the film in 2016 to cause some trouble and
get
people turning off their screens.
As for the publishing, I'll be making most if not all of the
interviews from this project freely available and licensed under
Creative Commons.  The film too itself will be available to view and
download for free, so as many people can see it as possible. This could
be another reason to help fund it. It's not for profit!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just
can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. Please get in
contact if you're able to offer a trade or want to donate some time and
energy or skills to do with a film project, or even if you simply want
to send me a message of support. That would be great.  You can also help
by asking others you may know who may wish to get involved or make a
donation. That would be great too.
Thank you!

Short Summary

<div>My name is Hannah Darby, and I'm the producer of Silver Moon Productions. As a team of second year Media Production students at the University of Lincoln, we're making a 10 minute short fiction film, from a script written by Hannah Darby &amp

The film's idea is a (55 year old) man, just returned from prison, who was sent there for murdering his wife, upon returning to his manor home, which was previously surrounded with life, it is now empty and alone. Throughout the story, his wife pops up in places, as a constant reminder to his mistakes, and not until the end of the story is it revealed that he killed her. 

What We Need &

Although our target shows £500, we are hoping to get in the region of £150-200 to assist with the production of our project. Fortunately, we have secured a brilliant location for our film: Harlaxton Manor, Grantham, which we hope will entice a brilliant cast to portray the characters of Clint and Sophia. 

Any help with paying for the production will go into the production budget, such as paying for food (on set), actors, travel etc. If we should be lucky enough to have any money left over from this budget, it will be reinvested into other crowd-funding projects for films.
<div>

The Impact

This project means a lot to the team, as it is the first script that both Hannah &
column2: Ben are having put through into production. Our team, consists of:

column1: Director/Editor: Dario Wilson
Born 14th April 1994 in the small
town in Nottingham, Dario has always had an interest in media. His education in
media started in The Meden School, where he studied A-level Media, English and
BTEC Drama. After achieving his grades Dario further perused his media career
by taking an advanced BTEC Film &amp
column2: Television course. Here Dario took the

column1: spotlight as the presenter for the live online television show “Gogglebox”. The
show was nominated for a national beacon award from the Association of
Colleges. He then advanced to The University of Lincoln where he continued to
study Film &amp
column2: Television. Throughout his time Dario has made and contributed

column1: to a variety of short films and documentaries including “Replica” and “Xbox
Voice Commands”. He is soon to be acting, directing and editing in other short
films over the course of 2016.
Producer: Hannah Darby
Born 15th
June 1995 in Barking, Essex, Hannah moved to Kent at a young age. Then when
starting secondary education she went to Invicta Grammar School, Maidstone.
Starting A-Levels she went on to study Business, Psychology and Media at
Maidstone Grammar School, where she then spent a brief time studying
Advertising at Edge Hill University, before moving to the University of Lincoln
to do Media Production. Throughout her time she has made a couple of short
films, including ‘MI5conception’ which received appraisal from the chief
examiners of the examining body, and ‘Encore: The Show Must Go On Documentary’,
and is soon to be co-producing a feature length film over the summer 2016.
Camera: Ben Peck
Born 18th
August 1996 in Kingston Upon Hull, East Yorkshire, Benjamin Jacob Peck knew he
wanted to be a filmmaker since he was at Hull Trinity House School. After
leaving School Ben got his first opportunity to explore the world of media, and
experiment with film and graphic design with his BTEC level 3 Media Production
course he did at Wilberforce College. From there Ben managed to be a runner for
Class Lane Media on their recruitment shot for the NHS of which got used by the
NHS across the globe. Ben then left Wilberforce College and moved onto the
University of Lincoln where he has directed two short films one fiction piece
and one documentary. And is currently working on writing a new short piece that
will hopefully be filmed in summer 2016.
Sound: Dan Wilson
Born 19th February 1995 in
Portsmouth, Hampshire. Daniel Wilson moved to Bridlington in East Yorkshire at
a young age of 6. Starting secondary education, an obvious appreciation was
aimed towards the creative arts. Starting A-Levels he went on to study Film
Studies, Media Studies, Physical Education and Computer Science at Headlands
School Sixth form. After achieving high results, he began studying Film and
Television studies at the University of Lincoln, and has been there for the
past 17 months. Throughout his time he has made a short drama film, known as
‘To Be' as the main camera operator. Recently he has aspired to work with
sounds used in film such as scores and effects, and hopes to gain full
understanding of this role.
Cinematographer: Rose Wilkinson
Born 25th July 1996 in Sutton-in-Ashfield,
attended Leamington primary and Sutton Centre Community College
studied Art &amp
column2: Design, Design Tech and Media, which is where her initial

column1: interest into media sparked. This then lead her into studying Media Production
at the University of Lincoln. Throughout her time in University she has
assisted in the production of a short film ‘Is Any One There?’ In which she was
the sound producer. During her brief stay in America on the Erasmus Exchange
Programme, she took the opportunity to study the journalistic side of the
media.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

As we have such a short time frame to do this project, we're having to drastically shorten the time we'd like to raise money over. The shoots will take place on Friday 19th February, Friday 26th February, and Friday 4th March in line with the available dates at Harlaxton Manor.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you're unable to donate to this cause, it'd still be brilliant to share the cause and hopefully raise enough money for this production to be above and beyond the average student film!

Short Summary

Hello explorers!

My name is Abby Thomas and I am the writer/producer of Explorer I.  I am currently a junior at Savanah College of Art and Design seeking a B.F.A. in Dramatic Writing and a minor in Producing for Film and Television.  Explorer I was a film I wrote with the intention of producing it immediately for my Production Practicum class.  However, the goals don't stop at class credit.  I also intend on posting this video online to start a following, then proceed with submitting it to film festivals.

Explorer I is a film about Nikki, a quiet girl, who gets inspired to go out and explore the city, and discovers that the little people you meet in life can change you.  I wrote this film out of my passion for exploring the city of Savannah, but even more than that, my passion for the search of one's self.  This film features a young girl who starts out incredibly innocent and naive, and by the end she has found her courage and strength while still keeping to who she is.

This film is going to be posted on the Internet to raise a following of all the crew and cast members, because nothing gets you jobs more often in this industry than having connections and people who know your name.  The goal is to build my own personal YouTube channel and empower other filmmakers at SCAD and in the Savannah area, then to also submit this to film festivals to further the following of the story line and the filmmakers involved.
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We are asking for $1500, and here's where your money would be going:

column1: •$175 will go toward a generator rental for camera and lighting
•$250 will go toward crafting and food for the cast and crew
•$75 will go toward costumes and props.
•$50 will go toward hair and makeup
• $300 will go toward copyright fees and other business fees to protect the film
•$50 will go toward gas for transportation
•$500 will go toward film festival fees and expenses
•$100 will go toward miscellaneous expenses and backup costs
Don't worry, we have some incentives for you to helps us out.
Perks:
The Fame Seeker Level: $10 or more and you will get social media shout outs with all the hash tags you can think of!
The Don't Press The Red Button Level:  $15 or more and you will get a personalized Explorer I button, as well as social media shout outs and fame.
The Getting Physical Level: $50 or more and you will get a physical copy of the film, as well as the social media shout outs.
The Being Recognized Level: $100 or more and you will get credit as a donor in the film, as well as social media fame and a physical copy of the film.

The Explorer Level: $250 or more and you will receive a personalized Savannah, Georgia trinket package that may include pictures, pins, T shirts, Irish figurines, ghost stories, and much more!  As well as credit as a donor, social media shout outs, and a physical copy of the film.

The Stealing My Job Level:  $500 or more and you will receive credit as an executive producer on the film, as well as a personalized Savannah, GA package, physical copy of the film, and social media shout outs.
If I weren't to reach the entire goal, then you should be ashamed of yourself.
Just kidding.

If I don't reach my entire goal, then the funds will first go toward catering, because people need to eat and keep the morale up, as well as a generator, because that's essential.  Then it will go toward hair, makeup, props, and costumes.  Then the post production and business aspects of the film.

The Impact

This project is valuable because it will benefit every person working on this film.  It will help us get our names out there for future jobs and a good reputation, and help us build something that we are passionate about.

It will also provide a strong female lead character that is also a good role model.  It will show people a type of city that isn't typically shown in movies, and hopefully benefit the Savannah community.  We already are advertising a local Savannah company Spudnik, and have a good track record with getting sponsors to sign on for the film such as Chipotle.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

The risks with this film is that there is no guaranteed monetary gain.  As a student, I am attempting to find people who will contribute as donors, but any funds that I do not find are going to come out of my own pocket.  However, I am confident that I will find donors and raise the money, because I am confident about this film.  As stated, we already have local restaurant Spudnik as a sponsor and Chipotle.  We are also looking into various soda companies and coat companies.  We are trying to be incredibly frugal and intelligent about our purchases, and I know that we can do it.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute the money, there are other ways you can help us out.

For starters, spread the word.  You can find us on Instagram, Twitter, and Snapchat as ExplorerOneFilm.  You can also find our Facebook page, Explorer I Film.  A link to those accounts is on this campaign.  Spread the word, and when we post the film online, we should have a huge following that we aim to spread like wildfire!
If you own a business that is willing to contribute food for the cast, costume pieces, or props, we could greatly appreciate your help, especially if you are in the Savannah, GA area.
Also, feel free to share the Indiegogo campaign!  Lets spread the word about Explorer I!

If I don't reach my entire goal, then the funds will first go toward catering, because people need to eat and keep the morale up, as well as a generator, because that's essential.  Then it will go toward hair, makeup, props, and costumes.  Then the post production and business aspects of the film.

The ImpactThis project is valuable because it will benefit every person working on this film.  It will help us get our names out there for future jobs and a good reputation, and help us build something that we are passionate about.It will also provide a strong female lead character that is also a good role model.  It will show people a type of city that isn't typically shown in movies, and hopefully benefit the Savannah community.  We already are advertising a local Savannah company Spudnik, and have a good track record with getting sponsors to sign on for the film such as Chipotle.

Risks & Challenges The risks with this film is that there is no guaranteed monetary gain.  As a student, I am attempting to find people who will contribute as donors, but any funds that I do not find are going to come out of my own pocket.  However, I am confident that I will find donors and raise the money, because I am confident about this film.  As stated, we already have local restaurant Spudnik as a sponsor and Chipotle.  We are also looking into various soda companies and coat companies.  We are trying to be incredibly frugal and intelligent about our purchases, and I know that we can do it.
Other Ways You Can Help If you cannot contribute the money, there are other ways you can help us out.

For starters, spread the word.  You can find us on Instagram, Twitter, and Snapchat as ExplorerOneFilm.  You can also find our Facebook page, Explorer I Film.  A link to those accounts is on this campaign.  Spread the word, and when we post the film online, we should have a huge following that we aim to spread like wildfire!
If you own a business that is willing to contribute food for the cast, costume pieces, or props, we could greatly appreciate your help, especially if you are in the Savannah, GA area.
Also, feel free to share the Indiegogo campaign!  Lets spread the word about Explorer I!",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Women writers and directors in the entertainment
industry constantly encounter roadblocks when attempting to advance their
careers – even when they are just as talented and capable as their male
counterparts. Women actors have a similar problem simply because the number of
female roles is significantly less than for men.
In our twenty years in the business as actors,
writers, and producers, we have personally witnessed the lack of opportunities
in this industry for women, and we’ve decided to do something about it.
Progress is being made.  There are a lot of great organizations these
days working to increase visibility and to provide more opportunities for
women, and we’ve decided to follow their lead and do our part. That is why we created our production company…
“Chicks Who Make Flicks.”
“Chicks
Who Make Flicks” is… films made by women, films that tell great woman’s
stories, films that capture the voices of women from all over the world and at
every stage of their life. Our goal is to create an environment that supports,
encourages, and celebrates talented female filmmakers.
We are launching our production company with two
films - “Waiting Room,” (a drama) and “Happy Hour” (a comedy).<span>  These two films are woman’s stories that are
real and relatable.
Now guys are welcome too, absolutely, but our
promise is to put a woman in at least one key role in every film –
writer/director/producer/etc. $9,000 is our budget for the two films - both to
be made in the next 6 months. The money goes for crew, set rental, insurance,
etc.
Every donation is truly welcomed and appreciated,
and we have some sweet perks. Whether it is 1 dollar or 100 dollars, it all
goes 100% to this project. We also really appreciate everyone spreading the word
- by mouth, email or social media! Please share our campaign with everybody you
know and help us make this happen!
A great story can inspire, motivate, and
illuminate – like powerful classics such as “Silkwood,” “Erin Brockovich” and
“Boys Don’t Cry.” So in addition to making movies, we want
to promote the healing power of art, as well, and pay it forward to a place
that is all about helping women - the Downtown Women’s Center. (www.DowntownWomensCenter.org) We have included $500 in our fundraising total as a donation to help
homeless women get off the street, get healthy, and ultimately reclaim their
lives.
Bottom line… While steps are being taken to fix
the inequality, women in the industry still need your help. Your donation to
this fundraiser achieves 3 things: 1) Helps fund two films, 2) provides
opportunities for women in the film industry, and 3) gives to a local women’s
charity. Where else does your money stretch that far?
Please join us in making “Chicks who make Flicks”
a reality.
We realize the two of us can’t change the world,
but with your help we can do our part - one woman, one story at a time.
Thanks,
Christina Gray and Amy Lloyd
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/chickswhomakeflicksprd

Twitter: @chicksflicksprd

Video music by: Music by Luis Oliart www.luisoliart.com

Video by : Paul Elliston http://paulelliston.prosite.com/
Other useful, interesting and helpful links:
Downtown Women’s Center: www.DowntownWomensCenter.org

Ms in the Biz: http://msinthebiz.com/

One Axe Plays: OneAxePlays.com

Women In Film:

http://www.wif.org/

We Make Movies: http://wemakemovies.org/

Short Summary
column5: >We are final year Film Production BSc students at Birmingham City University. We are all very proactive and passionate students and we want to exceed our brief. Instead of making a good 'student film', we want to make as good a short film as possible with the resources available to us.

column1: Bombshell is the story of 23 year old nurse Lena Chaunce. To her friends and family she's a responsible working adult
column2: good at her job and loved by her patients. However, underneath this exterior, Lena holds a secret. As a consequence of being addicted to the thrill of gambling, Lena has lost all of her money and is crumbling in serious debt. With a loan shark hot on her heel wanting his money back, Lena has to make a choice: One last gamble, or ultimate ruin.

column1: This campaign is important to us because it's our calling card. It's an example for all of us to show what we can do in an already very competitive industry. Rather than ask for your money up front and hope for the best, we have committed ourselves to this project and plunged right in. Without doing this, we wouldn't have been able to secure the resources we have. Your money will contribute to paying back the crew the money they put in up front. We hope that you are as excited about our project as we are and will regularly update you with our goings on . Please see the video above of us beavering away on the first night of our shoot,

We simply could not make this happen without the assistance of contributors. We do not receive funding from the university for this project. We have been incredibly fortunate to receive already this support:
-Permission to film in Lost and Found's secret bar in Birmingham city centre
-Permission from Film Birmingham to film exterior scenes
-BCU allowing us to be the first crew to take the Sony F55 off site.
-Birmingham School of Acting for providing us access to our talented cast.
-Midland Casino Hire for allowing us to use their equipment to recreate a Casino set.
<ul>

• We need £611.63 As a crew we will share the cost of food and transport for everyone (anyone who has filmed before will know this alone is no small feat!) Even without too many bells and whistles, filming alone throws up rapidly escalating costs just to begin. Please see below how your money will be spent
• £124.50 will go to Public and Employer Liability Insurance, necessary for filming in exterior locations and for our large crew.
• £301.13 will go towards insuring our equipment, including the particularly valuable Sony F55.
• £96 will pay for 5 pieces (yes, 5!) pieces of sugar glass so that we can safely smash a glass on set in a safe and controlled manner. (Stay tuned for an upload of glass smashing in slow motion!)
• £90 will go towards the car (a Mercedes E Class) we will be renting at an already reduced price for the purposes of filming in and around.

• Whatever money we make will go back towards these. If in the event we manage to exceed our target, this would go towards paying off petrol and food receipts and this will be itemised for transparency. 

    • The Impact
<ul>

• Student Film Makers get a bad rep. We want to demonstrate an array of ability that shows what can be done by going that extra mile. At the same time we're going to show you our journey and the scale involved.
• Come rain or shine this short film will be guaranteed a screening at the Electric Cinema in Birmingham later this year. We owe to ourselves to make it as impressive as possible.

• All of our crew have blossoming CV's and are passionate about their intentions to turn this passion into a career. Get in contact with us to chat if you wish to inquire as to crew members work outside of university and see examples of previous work. This includes music videos and promos, features, photo shoots and more.

• This project is real, and already happening. We just want you to be part of it. 

    • Risks &
column6:
>Risks involved: This is a deck of cards. Without a professional company behind us, every little thing has an impact, whether it's people not turning up or pulling out, permissions withdrawn or conditions changed. At the same time, this is part of Film making and nothing has stopped us yet. The equipment was a 'No', until it was 'Maybe', and then finally, a 'Yes'. Locations were too. Then the time frames were tightened. Individuals were unfortunately replaced. Schedules were rearranged. Regardless above is the footage of us turning up and getting on with it on the first night of the shoot, and everyone was great. It will be a long two weeks, but as someone who had the privilege to work on the '72 Project' Confusion of the Tongues (where a feature film was shot, edited and screened in Birmingham within 72 hours), this is nothing.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't give us money, it doesn't mean your contribution isn't important to us. You can share our page and talk about us. The more noise we make, the more we'll be heard. Thank you.

column1: • As the campaign goes on we'll be uploading more and more images and clips, so there'll be plenty to share.

• We are grateful for any contribution, big or small, so if you can only spare £1 we appreciate it so much.

    • And that's all there is to it.

The Project

Crazy For True is a psychological drama set in Britain, 1949. The main story follows Marianne Howard, 29, who is struggling with the loss of her parents, who were murdered by her estranged brother, Lesley. Now, living on her own, she feels as though can finally begin to get her life back on track.
That is until a strange man follows her home.

At first, she believes her mind is playing games, but as time passes items go missing from her apartment and the stranger continues to follow her. Marianne becomes convinced that her brother is back, only this time to kill her.

However, with no evidence to back up her claims, the police dismiss her case as a paranoid, young woman who is allowing her insecurities and fears about her past to take over her life. It is only when she becomes a victim of an attempted murder that all of Marianne's fears come true.

With the help of an unlikely friendship with DCI Ernest Hunter, together they uncover the dark truth about her assailant and the death of her parents. 

The Crew

The Budget

We have been graciously given a small budget from the Northern Film School, however this goes nowhere towards our goals for the production and film. We have a huge mission to create our own noir 1940's world and for that we will need a little bit extra funding to fufil our dreams for this film.
Please give anything you can afford and spread the word.
","The Project

Crazy For True is a psychological drama set in Britain, 1949. The main story follows Marianne Howard, 29, who is struggling with the loss of her parents, who were murdered by her estranged brother, Lesley. Now, living on her own, she feels as though can finally begin to get her life back on track.
That is until a strange man follows her home.

At first, she believes her mind is playing games, but as time passes items go missing from her apartment and the stranger continues to follow her. Marianne becomes convinced that her brother is back, only this time to kill her.

However, with no evidence to back up her claims, the police dismiss her case as a paranoid, young woman who is allowing her insecurities and fears about her past to take over her life. It is only when she becomes a victim of an attempted murder that all of Marianne's fears come true.
With the help of an unlikely friendship with DCI Ernest Hunter, together they uncover the dark truth about her assailant and the death of her parents.    The Crew.
We have a great crew of highly experienced film students working at 150% to come together and put the research in necessary for a 1940's noir film.

Our Director, who wrote the script, is tirelessly working on the script development to allow the crew to create the world of noir and the 1940's. With a huge passion and growing up with noir films, it is a personal project for the Director.

With an extensive crew of cinematographers, looking to challenge themselves by using complicated equipment in order for us to achieve the noir look needed by lighting, camera work and all that goes on behind the scenes.

Our lovely Production Designer has been working non-stop to research and gather props, costumes and furniture to create the era and a world we want the film to submerge the audience in. Not only that, but she is creating two set builds of a 1940's apartment which includes building the set, painting, wallpaper, skirting boards and layout.

Sound is working hard to create the diegetic world through sound to allow the audience to fall into, and believe the era as well as the story. Sound doesn't stop after the shoot, Sound Design is a hugely important part of the final stage of production. With sound effects, music and composing, the Sound Design will be working towards the final finished product by creating a polished soundtrack to increase the ambience needed for a film noir.
The editor will then have to piece the footage together with cuts, imagery, and transitions to ensure the film flows and tells the story in the 1940's world.

The Budget We have been graciously given a small budget from the Northern Film School, however this goes nowhere towards our goals for the production and film. We have a huge mission to create our own noir 1940's world and for that we will need a little bit extra funding to fufil our dreams for this film.
Please give anything you can afford and spread the word.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Leeds, United Kingdom",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/crazy-for-true/pica

Who, What, When and How

Hi, I’m David Roy Schwartz, filmmaker and former professor at Brooks Institute in Santa Barbara/Ventura, CA.  We are approximately one third of the way through principle photography on our feature film project, A Place Apart.  Savings/ retirement funds as well as favors and available resources have gotten us to where we are.  Now we're reaching out to all of you for additional funding and resources to complete the movie.

A Place Apart is about fear - the fear of failing your dream, your talent, your truest self.  AMY SUMAC has taken after her father, by always doing the expected at the expense of risk taking and self-discovery - until her now addled father no longer recognizes her, forcing Amy to reconsider her life and sense of purpose.  This is a story that hits close to home for me, as Alzheimer's disease runs in my family and claimed my mother's life.  It also prompted me to embark on a journey into uncharted territory, far off the beaten path I might otherwise have gone. 

The completion of A Place Apart will help achieve my dream of making films that offer more than the usual popcorn fare.  I’ve longed to tell stories about real people, real situations, hoping to shed some light on the mystery of what it means to be human.  The film we’re making is not a genre piece, nor is it a Hallmark movie.  It unflinchingly investigates the fear that often keeps us unfulfilled and unrealized.

Check out our webpage at aplaceapartthemovie.com and watch a two minute ""sample teaser"" of footage already shot. We are committed to maintaining the same high level of performance from our gifted cast, as well as the remarkable production value achieved by our small but highly talented crew.

Rewards as well as rewarding

Currently we’re one-third of the way complete.  Until recently, we’ve funded production with life savings but unfortunately can no longer do so.  We hope to raise $30,000. Your contributions will help with paying both cast and crew, as well as other costs such as insurance, permits, special equipment, catering, travel, lodging, editing, color grading, scoring, sound design and mixing.  All monies raised will go toward advancing the project as far as funds allow. In addition to funding, we're open to collaborating with potential production partners.  Whatever contribution you can make is deeply appreciated! 

Check out our perks – we welcome you as a member of our team!  Help us spread the word!

More info…

David Roy, Co-writer and Director was a professor at Brooks Institute for 15 years, teaching screenwriting, directing and film history. He was lauded by the Los Angeles Times for his first feature film, MAD SONG, citing it as “daring, dazzling” and ""one of the three most promising directorial debuts of the year"".  NPR’s nationally syndicated show, Movie Week cited MAD SONG as “an impressive indie film with a great visual style.” David is the recipient of a local Los Angeles Emmy for his work on THE LUCKY MAN, a documentary about Lou Gehrig’s disease.  In years past he has shot and directed award winning local and regional commercials, as well as editing a variety of music videos.

Karl Ulrich, Director of Photography, taught Cinematography at Brooks Institute for many years.  While studying at USC his visual skills helped earn major awards from The Director’s Guild of America and The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.  He has pursued his passion for cinema by shooting commercials, music videos and documentaries, as well as creating motion picture marketing materials for 20th Century Fox and other corporate clients.  He has also directed two award-winning short films and currently is directing and producing a feature-length documentary on the art of cinematography, with over 30 prominent ASC members participating.

Steven Argila, Composer, is a graduate of Julliard. He wrote the stirring score for David Roy’s Mad Song and has written music for The Paul Reiser Show, NBC and Nickelodeon.  His talents range from creating lush dramatic scores to quirky comedy cues and everything in between.  His latest project is the feature film Basmati Blues, starring Donald Sutherland and last year's Oscar-winning actor Brie Larson.   Steven composes, records, mixes and produces his film and TV scores, as well as pop records and classical recordings at 88 Keys Music, his personal studio in the heart of Silver Lake on the Eastside of Los Angeles.

Theresa Schwartz, Co-writer, Producer, A Place Apart is Theresa's first film project. Formerly a music teacher and school counselor, now a Life Coach and married to David Roy. 

Stefanie Estes, Lead,  is an award winning stage and film actress from Kailua, Hawaii.  She earned her BFA from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. While at NYU she studied with David Mamet's Atlantic Theater Company.  After graduation, Stefanie was selected as one of the 25 emerging artists to be part of Kevin Spacey's Old Vic: New Voices program in New York.  Stefanie has performed at various theaters in New York including: The Public Theater, Ars Nova, The Atlantic and Theater Row.  In Los Angeles, she has worked with The Blank Theater, Skylight Theater and A Working Theater.  Highlights from her film work including leading roles in ""When Harry Tries to Marry"" (Austin Film Festival), ""Mary Last Seen"" (Cannes &
column2:
Sundance Festivals) and the upcoming drama ""Nothing Like The Sun"".  

Jess Ford, Max Jess, originally from Phoenix, AZ, graduated from The Theatre Conservatory at Roosevelt University's Chicago College of the Performing Arts. A few years after school, he made his way to Los Angeles to pursue a career in film and television. Often referred to as a 'Jack of all trades' he takes pride in the diversity of his work, which includes musicals, plays, circus arts, music, writing, and more. He currently lives in Portland, OR, where he and his wife are founders of the Craftsman Theatre Company. dedicated to developing new works and adaptations for the stage.  A Place Apart will be Jess' feature film debut. 

Andrew Bering, Roger  Andrew is a Swiss/American, dual national, born and raised in Geneva Switzerland. He is a graduate of the Ecole de Theatre Serge Martin in Geneva, and has studied at the Lee Strasberg Theater and Film Institute in New York City. Andrew speaks unaccented French and English and has been working in theater and film projects on both sides of the Atlantic. He is currently based in Los Angeles.

Rachelle Carson, Marianne Rachelle Carson is an actress and producer, known for The Bling Ring (2013), But I'm a Cheerleader (1999) and Living with Ed (2007). She has been married to Ed Begley Jr. since August 23, 2000. They have one child.

Richard Neil, JJ Kinser  Born in New York City, a graduate of The Neighborhood Playhouse, where he studied with Sanford Meisner, Richard Neil was a key member of Chopstick Theatre in Charleston, S.C. He toured extensively, performing classic roles, such as Stanley Kowalski in A Streetcar Named Desire. He has appeared in two of Bill Viola's signature pieces, Ocean Without A Shore and Man With His Soul. He starred opposite Makoto Fujita in the Japanese actor's last film, Takashi Koizumi's Best Wishes For Tomorrow. Richard is also a voiceover actor. He is the brother of documentary filmmaker, Ellen Weissbrod.

David Yow, Bill  Well-schooled in acting techniques, improv and writing, David shines as a variety of characters, whether in front of the camera or behind a microphone doing voice-over. Mr. Yow is also known across the globe as the fiercely passionate lead singer for his band The Jesus Lizard.

","Who, What, When and HowHi, I’m David Roy Schwartz, filmmaker and former professor at Brooks Institute in Santa Barbara/Ventura, CA.  We are approximately one third of the way through principle photography on our feature film project, A Place Apart.  Savings/ retirement funds as well as favors and available resources have gotten us to where we are.  Now we're reaching out to all of you for additional funding and resources to complete the movie.A Place Apart is about fear - the fear of failing your dream, your talent, your truest self.  AMY SUMAC has taken after her father, by always doing the expected at the expense of risk taking and self-discovery - until her now addled father no longer recognizes her, forcing Amy to reconsider her life and sense of purpose.  This is a story that hits close to home for me, as Alzheimer's disease runs in my family and claimed my mother's life.  It also prompted me to embark on a journey into uncharted territory, far off the beaten path I might otherwise have gone. The completion of A Place Apart will help achieve my dream of making films that offer more than the usual popcorn fare.  I’ve longed to tell stories about real people, real situations, hoping to shed some light on the mystery of what it means to be human.  The film we’re making is not a genre piece, nor is it a Hallmark movie.  It unflinchingly investigates the fear that often keeps us unfulfilled and unrealized.Check out our webpage at aplaceapartthemovie.com and watch a two minute ""sample teaser"" of footage already shot. We are committed to maintaining the same high level of performance from our gifted cast, as well as the remarkable production value achieved by our small but highly talented crew.Rewards as well as rewardingCurrently we’re one-third of the way complete.  Until recently, we’ve funded production with life savings but unfortunately can no longer do so.  We hope to raise $30,000. Your contributions will help with paying both cast and crew, as well as other costs such as insurance, permits, special equipment, catering, travel, lodging, editing, color grading, scoring, sound design and mixing.  All monies raised will go toward advancing the project as far as funds allow. In addition to funding, we're open to collaborating with potential production partners.  Whatever contribution you can make is deeply appreciated! Check out our perks – we welcome you as a member of our team!  Help us spread the word!More info…David Roy, Co-writer and Director was a professor at Brooks Institute for 15 years, teaching screenwriting, directing and film history. He was lauded by the Los Angeles Times for his first feature film, MAD SONG, citing it as “daring, dazzling” and ""one of the three most promising directorial debuts of the year"".  NPR’s nationally syndicated show, Movie Week cited MAD SONG as “an impressive indie film with a great visual style.” David is the recipient of a local Los Angeles Emmy for his work on THE LUCKY MAN, a documentary about Lou Gehrig’s disease.  In years past he has shot and directed award winning local and regional commercials, as well as editing a variety of music videos.Karl Ulrich, Director of Photography, taught Cinematography at Brooks Institute for many years.  While studying at USC his visual skills helped earn major awards from The Director’s Guild of America and The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.  He has pursued his passion for cinema by shooting commercials, music videos and documentaries, as well as creating motion picture marketing materials for 20th Century Fox and other corporate clients.  He has also directed two award-winning short films and currently is directing and producing a feature-length documentary on the art of cinematography, with over 30 prominent ASC members participating.Steven Argila, Composer, is a graduate of Julliard. He wrote the stirring score for David Roy’s Mad Song and has written music for The Paul Reiser Show, NBC and Nickelodeon.  His talents range from creating lush dramatic scores to quirky comedy cues and everything in between.  His latest project is the feature film Basmati Blues, starring Donald Sutherland and last year's Oscar-winning actor Brie Larson.   Steven composes, records, mixes and produces his film and TV scores, as well as pop records and classical recordings at 88 Keys Music, his personal studio in the heart of Silver Lake on the Eastside of Los Angeles.Theresa Schwartz, Co-writer, Producer, A Place Apart is Theresa's first film project. Formerly a music teacher and school counselor, now a Life Coach and married to David Roy. Stefanie Estes, Lead,  is an award winning stage and film actress from Kailua, Hawaii.  She earned her BFA from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. While at NYU she studied with David Mamet's Atlantic Theater Company.  After graduation, Stefanie was selected as one of the 25 emerging artists to be part of Kevin Spacey's Old Vic: New Voices program in New York.  Stefanie has performed at various theaters in New York including: The Public Theater, Ars Nova, The Atlantic and Theater Row.  In Los Angeles, she has worked with The Blank Theater, Skylight Theater and A Working Theater.  Highlights from her film work including leading roles in ""When Harry Tries to Marry"" (Austin Film Festival), ""Mary Last Seen"" (Cannes & Sundance Festivals) and the upcoming drama ""Nothing Like The Sun"".  Jess Ford, Max Jess, originally from Phoenix, AZ, graduated from The Theatre Conservatory at Roosevelt University's Chicago College of the Performing Arts. A few years after school, he made his way to Los Angeles to pursue a career in film and television. Often referred to as a 'Jack of all trades' he takes pride in the diversity of his work, which includes musicals, plays, circus arts, music, writing, and more. He currently lives in Portland, OR, where he and his wife are founders of the Craftsman Theatre Company. dedicated to developing new works and adaptations for the stage.  A Place Apart will be Jess' feature film debut. Andrew Bering, Roger  Andrew is a Swiss/American, dual national, born and raised in Geneva Switzerland. He is a graduate of the Ecole de Theatre Serge Martin in Geneva, and has studied at the Lee Strasberg Theater and Film Institute in New York City. Andrew speaks unaccented French and English and has been working in theater and film projects on both sides of the Atlantic. He is currently based in Los Angeles.Rachelle Carson, Marianne Rachelle Carson is an actress and producer, known for The Bling Ring (2013), But I'm a Cheerleader (1999) and Living with Ed (2007). She has been married to Ed Begley Jr. since August 23, 2000. They have one child.Richard Neil, JJ Kinser  Born in New York City, a graduate of The Neighborhood Playhouse, where he studied with Sanford Meisner, Richard Neil was a key member of Chopstick Theatre in Charleston, S.C. He toured extensively, performing classic roles, such as Stanley Kowalski in A Streetcar Named Desire. He has appeared in two of Bill Viola's signature pieces, Ocean Without A Shore and Man With His Soul. He starred opposite Makoto Fujita in the Japanese actor's last film, Takashi Koizumi's Best Wishes For Tomorrow. Richard is also a voiceover actor. He is the brother of documentary filmmaker, Ellen Weissbrod.David Yow, Bill  Well-schooled in acting techniques, improv and writing, David shines as a variety of characters, whether in front of the camera or behind a microphone doing voice-over. Mr. Yow is also known across the globe as the fiercely passionate lead singer for his band The Jesus Lizard.",0.0,1,"1 Campaign

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h1><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
This will be based on the true
turn-of-the-century story of the last days of Edward Mordrake. He was a kind
man, but one who was stricken with a HIDEOUS deformity from birth. He was born with two faces, one in the front
and one in the back of his head. The second face would speak to Edward in the
midle of the night.
An heir to a peerage and a Symphony conductor
in his own right, he was accused of several murders, and he could neither
confirm nor deny that he had committed them.
He had some idea that his gruesome twin may have had something to do
with the murders after Edward himself, fell asleep.  His sad and bizarre life ended in suicide.
This will be a spectacular production that will
have a lot of action and amazing special effects.  Our script includes murders, fight scenes,
brain surgery, and a scene depicting the evils of Hell.  It will also be a lush production featuring
period-correct costumes, hair and make-up, as well as historic carriages and
other vehicles from the late 1800’s.  For
a backdrop, we will have famous European castles, and a symphony concert
performance.
<h3><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
Our goal, your perks
Our goal is to reach US$250,000 - which we realize is an ambitious
goal, but the making of a world-class movie such as this requires some major
investment.  As shown in the graph below,
we are allocating these funds to cover the costs of the film’s pre-production,
shooting schedule, post-production work, and pre-marketing/ distribution,
as well as some handsome perks for our investors, plus our Indiegogo fees. The
planned release date for the movie is October 2017.
The US$250,000 will cover the entire filming
process from start to finish - including:
•  Victorian
locations, castles, the concert hall and downtown
London exteriors. Wardrobe will consist of period-correct Victorian time
clothing for both Principals and extras.
Much of it can be rented, but the Principals costumes will all be
gorgeously custom-designed.
•  Props
and furnishings, such as the carriages and buggies for the outdoor scenes,
musical instruments for the orchestra scenes, Victorian furnishing for the
indoor shots, and many other items necessary to create the reality of Edward's
last days.
•  We
are in the process of designing our special effects.  We will use some green screen technologies
and a morphing like process much like the one in Benjamin Button to make
Edward’s second face have a distinctive look and personality all of its own.
•  We
have worked hard to come up with some much sought-after perks to honor our
donors.  Some of the options available
are to have your name on the credits, be part of the filmmaking process by
being an extra, have a dinner with the cast, visit the film shoot while in
production and be invited to the movie’s Premiere, plus some exclusive
t-shirts, mugs, posters and an Edward Mordrake 12"" doll.
<div>
<div>
<i style=""font-size: 36px
<div>
<div>
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>
<h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
In his time, the story of Edward Mordrake was
too gruesome and completely misunderstood, because Edward's doctor only wrote
one page about Edward's life.  Everything
else about his story was fabricated from gossip and speculation.  Now, with the magic of film, we can now
fathom what it would have been like to be in Edward's head.
You will be part of the filmmaking process
which takes places in Victorian England in 1895. The terrifying story of
Edward Mordrake and his psychological battle with his disfigured evil twin
brother will come to life before your eyes.
Writer/ Director Mark Christensen has worked with such stars as
Danny Trejo, Douglas Spain and Patricia Rae. To learn more about the
Director's history click to visit his IMDB
profile.
""For some unforgiven wickedness of my forefathers I am knit to this fiend""
<div>
""For a fiend it surely is. I beg and beseech you to crush it out of human semblance, even if I die for it before it kills again""
<div>
<h2>Risks &amp
All projects face risks and ours is no
different.  We might not reach our
goal.  That is possible with any
campaign.  However, we are determined to
bring this project to the screen in the best way possible.  If we do not reach the entire funding goal we
will shoot the film with what we raised from this campaign and what we can
raise from private investors.
column2: >In terms of shipping Pledge Rewards to those of you generous enough to merit a physical token of our gratitude, we do not have a logistical supply chain as we are not a commercial focused sellers but only a dedicated team of creative professionals focused on filming industry. We will do our best to ship your Pledge Reward package as soon as the Edward Mordrake Movie is complete.

column1: Why crowd funding?
We decided to turn to crowd
funding to reduce our dependence on traditional film business interests, to
build valuable awareness for our project and to offer fans the opportunity to become
involved and co-create this project with us, while protecting the integrity of
the subject matter.

<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
